# Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>
## Decree-Law No. 78 of 2025
Amending certain provisions of Law No. 17 of 1973
regarding Judicial Fees
- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 G,
- And Law No. (17) of 1973 regarding Judicial Fees,
- And the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law issued by Decree-Law No. (38) of 1980, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (39) of 1980 regarding Evidence in Civil and Commercial Matters, and its amending laws,
- And the Law on the Organization of Expertise issued by Decree-Law No. (40) of 1980, and its amending laws,
- And the Law on the Organization of the Judiciary issued by Decree-Law No. (23) of 1990, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (11) of 1995 regarding Judicial Arbitration in Civil and Commercial Matters, and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (71) of 2020 issuing the Bankruptcy Law, as amended by Law No. 58 of 2025,
- And upon the submission of the Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig>,
- And after the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:
### Article One
The texts of Articles (2, 5, 6, 7, 8 first paragraph, 9, 10, 15, 16, 17, 18 first paragraph, 19, 22, and 23) of the aforementioned Law No. 17 of 1973 shall be replaced with the following texts:
### Article (2)
If the lawsuit includes multiple claims of known value, whether principal or principal and alternative, arising from a single legal cause, the valuation shall be based on their total value. However, if they arise from different legal causes, the valuation shall be based on the value of each claim separately.

### Article (5)
If it is impossible to assess the value of a lawsuit, the lawsuit shall be considered of unassessed value. The following lawsuits, in particular, shall be considered of unassessed value:
a- Lawsuits for the validity of a signature.
b- Lawsuits and disputes submitted to the Judge of Summary Matters.
c- Original forgery lawsuits.
d- Requests to affix the executory formula to arbitrators' awards and grievances against this order.
e- Petitions for orders to enforce foreign court judgments.
f- Requests for the recusal of judges, experts, and arbitrators.
g- Petitions and orders on petitions submitted to the Enforcement Directorate and grievances against them.
h- Easement rights lawsuits.
i- Lawsuits for the interpretation and correction of judgments.
j- Lawsuits concerning the supervision of a Waqf <orig>وقف</orig> and lawsuits for the entitlement to housing in Waqf <orig>وقف</orig> properties or their eviction.
k- Lawsuits for the eviction of leased premises.
### Article (6):
A proportional fee shall be imposed on lawsuits of known value as follows:
a- 5% up to thirty thousand dinars.
b- 3.5% for amounts exceeding thirty thousand dinars up to one hundred and fifty thousand dinars.
c- 2.5% for amounts exceeding one hundred and fifty thousand dinars up to five hundred thousand dinars.
d- 1.5% for amounts exceeding five hundred thousand dinars up to five million dinars.
e- 1% for amounts exceeding five million dinars.
In no case shall the fee be less than ten dinars.
### Article (7)
A fixed fee shall be imposed on lawsuits of unassessed value as follows:
a- Ten dinars for petitions and orders on petitions submitted to the Enforcement Directorate.
b- Fifty dinars for petitions submitted to the Judge of Provisional Matters, lawsuits filed with the Judge of Summary Matters, and petitions in summary matters submitted to the court of substance ancillary to the substantive claims.
c- One hundred dinars for lawsuits filed initially before the Court of First Instance (Partial), the Court of First Instance (Plenary), the Court of Appeal, or the Court of Cassation.
d- One hundred and fifty dinars for lawsuits concerning provisional enforcement disputes filed with the Judge of Summary Matters.
e- Three hundred dinars for requests for the recusal of a judge, expert, or arbitrator, and the fee shall be multiplied by the number of individuals whose recusal is requested.
f- Five hundred dinars for requests to refer real estate to the Sales Judge in preparation for its sale by auction.
### Article (8, first paragraph):
If a lawsuit includes multiple original claims, or original and alternative claims, all of which are of unassessed value, a separate fee shall be imposed on each. If these claims are related, a single fee shall be imposed.
### Article (9)
A fixed fee shall be imposed on the following lawsuits:
a- Personal status lawsuits of all types.
b- Partition lawsuits between partners.
c- Grievances against orders on petitions, and against the list of fees, expenses, and charges.
### Article (10):
Fees shall be collected for every lawsuit for which one year has passed since the date it was struck off and not renewed, or since the end of the period of punitive or consensual stay and was not

A fee of five dinars shall be imposed on a request to renew a case after it has been struck off the roll, to shorten the date of its session, or to expedite it from a punitive or consensual stay. The applicant shall be liable for this fee regardless of the outcome of the case.
New fees shall be collected for the case at a rate of 10% of the value of the fee due when it was first filed, if it is re-filed within three months from the date of the judgment deeming it as if it never was or by its abandonment, provided that the subject matter of the case or the litigants therein do not change.

## Article (15)
A request for exemption shall be submitted to the Clerks' Department of the Court of First Instance, accompanied by the supporting documents or copies thereof. The Clerks' Department shall notify the Judicial Fees Department of the request and its documents, for the latter to submit its report thereon.
A committee of three judges shall be formed to decide on the request in the absence of the litigants and without a hearing, unless the committee deems their presence necessary. The committee shall have a secretary who attends its sessions and records its minutes. The committee's decision shall be issued by a majority of its members' votes and shall include its reasoning and the grounds on which it relied to verify the state of incapacity justifying the exemption.
The exemption from fees shall be personal, and its effect shall not extend to the heirs of the exempted person or whoever replaces them.

## Article (16)
The committee referred to in the preceding article may, during the course of the case or after the judgment therein, upon the request of the Judicial Fees Department or the opposing party in the case, revoke the exemption decision if it is proven that the state of incapacity justifying the exemption has ceased.
The court's Clerks' Department shall notify the circuit hearing the case of the revocation decision.

## Article (17)
If the opponent of the exempted person is ordered to pay the fees, he must be claimed from first. If it is not possible to collect them from him, recourse may be had against the exempted person if his state of incapacity has ceased in accordance with the preceding article.

## Article (18, first paragraph):
A fee of five dinars shall be imposed on notices and summonses—other than the service of the statement of claim, the judgment, and other summonses related to the proceedings of a dispute pending before the judiciary—for each person served.

## Article (19)
A fee of half a dinar shall be imposed for each page of a copy of the judgment requested by non-litigants. The same fee shall be imposed for each page requested by the litigants after they have received the first copy, or by others regarding the progress of the case or the judgment therein.

## Article (22)
The courts shall decide on cases and requests for which the fee is paid in advance, or for which a temporary exemption is proven. No case or request may be initiated before this fee is paid. If it is found that it has not been paid, the court shall grant the plaintiff a suitable period for payment. If he fails to pay within that period without an acceptable excuse, a judgment must be issued deeming the case as if it never was.

## Article (23)
The provisions of Article 123 of the aforementioned Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure shall apply to orders for the assessment of fees and grievances against them.
Without prejudice to the rules for exemption from judicial fees, the plaintiff is obligated to pay the fee until a final judgment is rendered against the other party for it.

## Article Two
The following two clauses, (f) and (g), shall be added to the text of Article (4) of the aforementioned Law No. 17 of 1973:
f- Lawsuits for the annulment of judgments by courts, judicial bodies, and arbitrators shall be assessed based on the value awarded in the judgment.
g- The value of requests related to letters of guarantee shall be assessed based on their value, unless the dispute is limited to a part thereof, in which case it shall be assessed according to that part.

## Article Three
The Prime Minister and the Ministers, each within his own jurisdiction, shall implement this Decree-Law. It shall be published in the Official Gazette and shall come into force from the date of its publication.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1746, Seventy-first Year 4

4 Sunday, 11 Muharram 1447 H - 6/7/2025 G

For all these considerations, and as the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/5/2024, Article (4) of which stipulates that laws shall be issued by decrees-by-law, the present draft decree-by-law has been prepared. Its first article provides for the replacement of a number of articles of the aforementioned Law No. 17 of 1973. The texts of Articles (2) and (8), first paragraph, were replaced by adding the phrase "(principal or principal and alternative)," in the context of specifying multiple claims, to make it clearer as dictated by good drafting, and as it is known that a plaintiff may have principal and alternative claims.
It was deemed appropriate to replace the text of Article (5), rephrasing and rearranging its clauses in light of the deletion of the phrase "opposition by a non-bankrupt party to the declaration of bankruptcy and all subsidiary claims related to the bankruptcy," which was in clause (d). This is because the Executive Regulations <orig>اللائحة التنفيذية</orig> of the Bankruptcy Law <orig>قانون الإفلاس</orig> issued by Law No. (71) of 2020 addressed the amount of judicial fees <orig>الرسوم القضائية</orig> due for all lawsuits, applications, grievances, and appeals related to bankruptcy, which necessitated the deletion of that phrase in this draft. It was also deemed appropriate to add the phrase "applications and orders on petitions <orig>الطلبات والأوامر على عرائض</orig> submitted to the Execution Department <orig>إدارة التنفيذ</orig> and grievances against them" to clause (g), considering that these applications are of unquantifiable value.
This draft has codified a considered and fair increase in judicial fees, replacing the text of Article (6) of the aforementioned Law No. 17 of 1973, with the aim of reassessing the proportional fees imposed on lawsuits of quantifiable value. It imposes fees as a percentage of the claim value, which are (5%) up to thirty thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, 3.5% for amounts exceeding thirty thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig> up to one hundred and fifty thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, 2.5% for amounts exceeding one hundred and fifty thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig> up to five hundred thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, 1.5% for amounts exceeding five hundred thousand dinars <orig>دينار</orig> up to five million dinars <orig>دينار</orig>, and 1% for amounts exceeding five million dinars <orig>دينار</orig>). These brackets are calculated progressively, meaning the fees are not deducted from the total amount but are collected gradually according to the preceding brackets. The text also introduced a provision for a minimum prescribed fee of ten dinars <orig>دنانير</orig>.
The draft also replaced the text of Article (7), reassessing the fixed fee imposed on lawsuits of unquantifiable value. It imposes a fee of ten dinars <orig>دنانير</orig> for applications and orders on petitions <orig>الأوامر على عرائض</orig> submitted to the Execution Department <orig>إدارة التنفيذ</orig>; fifty dinars <orig>ديناراً</orig> for applications submitted to the judge of summary matters <orig>قاضي الأمور الوقتية</orig>, lawsuits filed with the judge of urgent matters <orig>قاضي الأمور المستعجلة</orig>, and applications in urgent matters submitted to the trial court ancillary to the substantive claims; one hundred dinars <orig>دينار</orig> for lawsuits filed initially before the Court of First Instance (Partial Circuit) <orig>المحكمة الجزئية</orig>, the Court of First Instance (Plenary Circuit) <orig>الكلية</orig>, the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig>, or the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig>; one hundred and fifty dinars <orig>ديناراً</orig> for lawsuits concerning temporary execution disputes <orig>إشكالات التنفيذ الوقتية</orig> before the judge of urgent matters; three hundred dinars <orig>دينار</orig> for requests for the recusal of a judge, expert, or arbitrator, emphasizing that the prescribed fee is multiplied by the number of individuals whose recusal is sought; and five hundred dinars <orig>دينار</orig> for requests to refer real estate to the sales judge <orig>قاضي البيوع</orig> in preparation for its sale by auction.
The draft then replaced the text of Article (9), limiting its provision to imposing a fixed fee on personal status lawsuits <orig>الدعاوى المتعلقة بالأحوال الشخصية</orig> of all types, partnership partition lawsuits, and grievances against orders on petitions <orig>الأوامر على عرائض</orig>, including grievances against the list of fees, expenses, and costs. The draft also replaced the text of Article (10), introducing a new provision to collect fees on those lawsuits that have been struck out for one year without being renewed, or for which the period of punitive or consensual stay <orig>الوقف الجزائي أو الاتفاقي</orig> has expired without proceedings being resumed. This is because practical experience has shown that some plaintiffs—who have obtained a decision from the exemption committee for a temporary waiver of judicial fees—file their lawsuits and then deliberately fail to appear during the proceedings, leading the court to issue a decision to strike out the case. This is done either because they anticipate losing their case and wish to avoid a judgment dismissing their claim and ordering them to pay costs, or because they have settled with the defendants outside the courtroom. Consequently, the lawsuits remain struck out for a full year. Since no final, conclusive judgment resolving the dispute has been issued in these cases, this poses an obstacle for the judicial fees administration in collecting fees from those liable to pay them. The same applies to lawsuits in which a judgment of punitive or consensual stay was issued and a year has passed without proceedings being resumed. Furthermore, to regulate the stability of litigation procedures, ensure they are not perpetuated, and encourage the plaintiff to pursue their lawsuit, the same text imposes a fixed fee of five dinars <orig>دنانير</orig> on requests to renew lawsuits that have been struck out, to shorten their hearing dates, or to expedite them after a punitive or consensual stay, with the applicant being liable for this fee.

<header>
Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1746, Seventy-first Year, Sunday, 11 Muharram 1447 H - 6/7/2025 AD
</header>


The draft reorganized the procedures and conditions for exemption from judicial fees in a manner that guarantees a litigant whose inability is proven is exempted from paying the prescribed judicial fees, and to limit, as much as possible, the phenomenon of unwarranted resort to exemption requests. It was decided to replace the text of Article (15) to stipulate that an exemption request submitted to the Clerks' Department <orig>إدارة الكتاب</orig> at the Court of First Instance <orig>المحكمة الكلية</orig> must be accompanied by all supporting documents or copies thereof. The Clerks' Department must notify the Judicial Fees Department <orig>إدارة الرسوم القضائية</orig> of the applicant and their documents, so that it may submit its report on each request. It was also decided that the text should include a new composition for the Exemption Committee <orig>لجنة الإعفاء</orig>, which is now formed of three judges—in contrast to the current text where the committee was formed of one judge and a member of the Public Prosecution <orig>نيابة عامة</orig>. This change is due to the fact that practical experience has shown the limited role of the Public Prosecution member in this exemption process. Furthermore, forming the committee of three judges would reduce the likelihood of error in their decision and ensure a swift resolution, especially since this is generally done in the absence of the litigants and without a hearing—unless the committee deems their presence necessary. It issues its decision by a majority vote of its members, including its reasoning when granting the exemption request, and stating the grounds on which the state of inability was established.
The draft included a replacement for the text of Article (16), whereby the Judicial Fees Department <orig>إدارة الرسوم القضائية</orig> now has the right to directly request the aforementioned committee to annul the exemption decision. It also became mandatory for the Clerks' Department of the Court of First Instance <orig>إدارة كتاب المحكمة الكلية</orig> to notify the circuit still hearing the case of the annulment decision issued by the committee. The draft also replaced the text of Article (17) in a manner consistent with the text of the preceding article.
The draft proposed raising the judicial fees for notices, announcements, requests for copies of judgments by non-litigants, and other documents specified in the texts of Articles (18, first paragraph) and (19) of the law, to ensure the optimal use of the judicial service provided to the applicant.
Since a judgment deeming a lawsuit null and void is a judgment that terminates the litigation and nullifies all its effects, and does not rule on the right claimed in the lawsuit should the plaintiff wish to refile it, it was decided to replace the text of Article (22) so that a judgment deeming the lawsuit null and void becomes the inevitable consequence of the plaintiff's failure to pay the prescribed fee for their motions after the expiration of the appropriate period granted by the court, provided the non-payment was without an acceptable excuse. This consequence, once its conditions are met, must be applied by the court on its own initiative and without need for a plea. The reason for this new provision is what practical experience has revealed: plaintiffs' casual refusal to pay the fees due on their motions during the hearing of the case, and the reluctance of some judicial circuits to decide to dismiss the lawsuit or motion for which the fee was not paid as stipulated in the current text, which resulted in the loss of the opportunity to collect these fees for the Public Treasury <orig>الخزانة العامة</orig> promptly.
As Law No. 17 of 1973, aforementioned, was promulgated before the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law issued by Decree-Law No. 38 of 1980, aforementioned, it was therefore decided to replace the text of Article (23) of the Judicial Fees Law in a way that aligns with the rules contained in Article (123) of the Civil and Commercial Procedures Law concerning the assessment of fee orders and grievances against them. The draft also introduced a second paragraph to that article, which states that without prejudice to the rules for exemption from judicial fees, the applicant "the plaintiff" is obligated to pay the fee until it is finally ruled to be borne by the other party. The justification for this new provision is that the legislator intended for the submission of the statement of claim or the incidental motion to the court to be the event that creates the right to collect the judicial fees due to the Public Treasury <orig>الخزانة العامة</orig> for it. And that the plaintiff is obligated to pay the fee due on the lawsuit they file or the motion they submit once the lawsuit or motion is legally brought before the court. Thus, the Judicial Fees Department <orig>إدارة الرسوم القضائية</orig> has the right to demand from the plaintiff the fees due on the lawsuit they file or the motion they submit, while it does not have the right to demand it from the defendant except when the latter is finally ordered to pay the litigation costs, which is precisely what the rulings of the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> have established.
Article Two of the present draft stipulated the addition of clauses (f) and (g) to the text of Article (4) of the aforementioned Law No. 17 of 1973, to specify the judicial fees due on certain lawsuits of known value that were not provided for in the existing law. These are lawsuits for the annulment of judgments by courts, judicial bodies, and arbitrators, where the fee is assessed based on the value awarded in the judgment, as well as motions related to letters of guarantee, where the fee is assessed based on their value, unless the dispute is limited to a part thereof, in which case it is assessed according to that part. The draft intentionally used the phrase "judicial bodies <orig>الجهات القضائية</orig>" in the said text to accommodate the establishment of any judicial body, whether composed of judicial elements or a mix of judicial and non-judicial elements, to adjudicate specific disputes. This is inferred from the text of Articles (95) and (173) of the Constitution, where the constitutional legislator used the phrase "judicial body <orig>جهة قضائية</orig>".
Article Three of the present draft obligates the Prime Minister <orig>رئيس مجلس الوزراء</orig>, and the Ministers, each within their respective jurisdictions, to implement this Decree-Law, and it shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.
<page_end>5</page_end>

# Decree-Law No. 79 of 2025
## Concerning International Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qi'dah 1445 AH, corresponding to May 10, 2024 AD,
- And the Penal Code promulgated by Law No. (16) of 1960 and its amending laws,
- And the Code of Criminal Procedure and Trials promulgated by Law No. (17) of 1960 and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (40) of 1972 concerning cases and procedures for cassation appeals and its amending laws,
- And the Civil and Commercial Procedure Law promulgated by Decree-Law No. (38) of 1980 and its amending laws,
- And the Law on the Organization of the Judiciary promulgated by Decree-Law No. (23) of 1990 and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (1) of 1993 concerning the protection of public funds and its amending laws,
- And Law No. (106) of 2013 concerning combating money laundering and terrorism financing, as amended by Law No. (24) of 2016,
- And upon the proposal of the Minister of Justice <orig>وزير العدل</orig>,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers <orig>مجلس الوزراء</orig>,
- We have issued the following Decree-Law:

## Part One: General Provisions

### Article (1)
For the purposes of applying the provisions of this Decree-Law, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings assigned to each, unless the context requires otherwise:
**The State:** The State of Kuwait.
**International Judicial Cooperation:** The set of legal procedures undertaken based on international agreements to which the State is a party, or in accordance with the principle of reciprocity, for the purpose of extraditing persons, transferring sentenced persons, and providing judicial assistance in criminal matters.
**Criminal Matters:** Investigations, trials, and criminal penalties and their related procedures.
**Judicial Assistance:** Any procedure requested by one state from another to support investigations or trials conducted therein, or to enforce criminal judgments issued by its competent courts, including requests for the extradition of persons, sentenced persons, or objects, documents, collection of evidence, hearing of witnesses, execution of judicial orders, freezing and seizure of funds and assets, their confiscation, and the exchange of information relevant to criminal matters.
**Reciprocity:** The commitment of a state to grant another state the same rights and facilities in the field of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, to achieve balance and justice in international relations in the absence of international agreements regulating these matters between the two states.
**Requesting State:** The foreign state requesting judicial assistance from the authorities of the State.
**Requested State:** The foreign state from which judicial assistance is requested.
**Extradition Requests:** Requests submitted to the State concerning a person sought for extradition.
**Person Sought for Extradition:** Any person within the State who is sought for extradition or temporary arrest due to an investigation, accusation, or criminal judgment issued by a foreign judicial authority.
**Person Sought for Surrender:** Any person sought for surrender from abroad as a result of an investigation, accusation, or criminal judgment issued against them by the courts of the State.
**Sentenced Person:** Any person against whom a final and enforceable judicial judgment has been issued for a custodial sentence by the courts of the State, or by the courts of another state, and the state of enforcement requests their transfer to it to execute or complete the execution of the sentence imposed upon them.
**State of Enforcement:** The state to which the sentenced person is transferred to execute the imposed sentence or the remainder thereof.

### Article (2)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party or the principle of reciprocity, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall be competent to exchange requests for international judicial cooperation in accordance with the procedures and rules stipulated in this Decree-Law, through diplomatic channels, unless an international agreement to which the State is a party provides otherwise.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may, in cases that so require, exchange these requests directly with the competent foreign authority using any other means acceptable to both parties.

## Part Two: Extradition of Persons and Objects
### Chapter One: Extradition of Persons

### Article (3)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall be responsible for receiving extradition requests from the competent foreign authorities in other countries, and shall also be responsible for initiating extradition proceedings before the competent court based on those requests in preparation for their execution.
Extradition shall be carried out to the competent authority in the Requesting State for the investigation of the persons sought for extradition, their criminal prosecution, or the execution of criminal judgments issued against them, in accordance with the provisions contained in this chapter.

### Article (4)
The following conditions must be met for extradition:
1- The offense for which extradition is requested must be punishable under the laws of both the Requesting State and the Requested State.
It is not required for the offense to be considered punishable under the laws of both countries that its name, description, or elements be identical.
2- The offense must be punishable by, or have been sentenced with, a custodial penalty of no less than one year under the laws of both the Requesting and Requested States.
3- The execution of the extradition request must not result in the person sought for extradition being punished twice for the same offense.
Extradition shall not be granted in the following cases:
## Article (5)
1- If the person sought for extradition is a Kuwaiti national, in which case they shall be referred to the competent investigation and prosecution authority if the extradition request meets the conditions stipulated in the preceding article.

<header>Kuwait Today / Al-Kuwait Al-Youm <orig>الكويت اليوم</orig> Issue 1746 Year Seventy-One 7 Sunday, 11 Muharram 1447 AH - July 6, 2025 AD</header>


2- The execution of the extradition request conflicts with the sovereignty of the State, its national security, or its public order.
3- If the law grants jurisdiction to the competent judicial authority in the State over the offense for which extradition is requested.
4- If the offense subject to the extradition request is a political offense or is connected to a political offense.
The following shall not be considered political offenses: crimes of terrorism, war crimes, crimes of genocide, crimes against the Head of State, a member of his family, his deputy, or other internationally protected persons, as well as crimes of assault against the State's facilities and political interests.
5- If the offense for which extradition is requested is exclusively a breach of military duties.
6- If there are serious grounds to believe that the extradition request is intended for prosecuting or punishing the person sought for reasons related to their ethnic origin, religion, nationality, or political opinions.
7- If the person sought has already been tried for the same offense for which extradition is requested and was acquitted, or was convicted and has served the sentence imposed.
8- If the person sought is under investigation or on trial in the State for the same offense for which extradition is requested.
9- If the offense or the penalty associated with the offense for which extradition is requested has become statute-barred by the lapse of time according to the law of the State where it was committed.
10- If the person sought has been or may be subjected in the requesting State to torture, inhuman or degrading treatment, or a cruel penalty disproportionate to the offense committed, or will not be afforded the fair trial guarantees stipulated in international covenants.

## Article (6)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, the extradition request must be submitted in writing in the Arabic language through diplomatic channels to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>, accompanied by the following data and documents:
1- A detailed statement of the identity of the person sought, their description, personal photograph, fingerprints, if possible, and any other data that may help in determining their identity, nationality, and place of residence.
2- An arrest warrant, or any other document having the same effect, issued by the competent authority in the requesting State, indicating the type of offense attributed to the person sought, with a precise description of their role in it, the time and place of its commission, and the judicial proceedings taken against them, if the request pertains to a person under investigation or on trial.
3- The legal basis for submitting the extradition request.
4- A statement of the date and place of commission of the offense for which extradition is requested, its legal characterization, the applicable legal provisions, the provisions on the statute of limitations for the criminal action and the prescription of its penalty, with a copy of these provisions and the evidence against the person sought attached.
5- An official copy of the conviction judgment against the person sought, if any, whether in personam or in absentia, the penalty imposed, and a statement that the conviction is enforceable, if the request pertains to the extradition of a convicted person.
6- Any additional data or information requested by the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> from the requesting State, provided that this data or information is sent within a period not exceeding (30) days from the date of the request. The person sought shall be released, if under arrest, should this period be exceeded without receiving the requested items.

## Article (7)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may order the arrest of the person sought once it has verified that the necessary conditions for extradition are met.
The person sought shall be brought before the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> within (48) hours of their arrest and shall be informed of the reason for their arrest. Their statements shall be recorded in an official report, and they have the right to have a lawyer present when their statements are heard.

## Article (8)
Without prejudice to the provision of Clause (6) of Article (6) of this Decree-Law, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may order the detention of the person sought based on an arrest warrant issued by a foreign judicial authority for a period of (30) days, renewable once.

## Article (9)
If the extradition request includes more than one offense, and one of them meets the conditions set out in Article (4) of this Decree-Law, the requesting State, if it wishes to proceed with the extradition, must provide a written undertaking to limit the prosecution or enforcement procedures to this offense.

## Article (10)
Consideration of the extradition request shall be postponed in the following cases:
1- If the person sought is under investigation or on trial in the State for an offense other than the one for which extradition is requested.
2- If the person sought is serving a sentence imposed on them for an offense other than the one for which extradition is requested.
3- If the person sought is subject to a travel ban for a reason other than the offense for which extradition is requested.
The postponement shall continue until the investigation or trial is concluded, the imposed sentence is served, or the travel ban is lifted, as the case may be.

## Article (11)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, the priority for extradition in the event of multiple extradition requests for a single offense shall be as follows:
1- The State in whose territory the offense was committed.
2- The State whose interests were harmed by the offense.
3- The State of which the person sought is a national.
If the circumstances are the same, priority shall be given to the State that submitted its request first.

However, if the extradition requests are for multiple crimes, priority among them shall be determined according to the circumstances of the crime, its gravity, the place of its commission, the nationality of the person sought for extradition, and the precedence of the date of receipt of these requests, as determined by the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in this regard.

## Article (12)
The extradition request received from the requesting authority shall be executed immediately if the person sought for extradition agrees in writing to the extradition before the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> or the competent court hearing the extradition case. In this case, his legal capacity and his understanding of the consequences of his consent must be verified.
If the consent is given before the court, the papers and their attachments shall be returned to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> to proceed with the extradition procedures.
If the person sought for extradition does not consent to the request, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall initiate the extradition proceedings based on the documents and records submitted by the requesting state. For this purpose, the Public Prosecution may conduct the necessary investigations to support the request.
The extradition case shall be filed before the Criminal Court <orig>محكمة الجنايات</orig> by means of a statement of claim that includes the data or information stipulated in Article (6) of this Decree-Law, and in accordance with the procedures prescribed for filing criminal cases in felony matters as stipulated in the aforementioned Code of Criminal Procedure and Trials. The procedures, rules, and guarantees stipulated therein shall apply to all its stages, in a manner that does not conflict with the provisions of this Decree-Law.
The court shall decide the case expeditiously.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>, or the convicted person, may appeal the judgment issued by the Criminal Court <orig>محكمة الجنايات</orig> within (30) days before the Court of Appeal, and the judgment issued by the court shall be subject to appeal before the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> in accordance with the same rules and procedures prescribed for appealing criminal judgments.
In all cases, the judgment issued in this case may not be challenged by way of opposition.
The judgment ordering extradition may not be executed until it becomes final and unappealable.

## Article (13)
The period for appealing the judgment issued in an extradition case begins from the date of its pronouncement, unless otherwise stipulated. This period begins from the date the judgment is served on the convicted person if he fails to attend all the sessions scheduled for hearing the case, or the subsequent sessions for its expedition after its sequential progress was hindered for any reason, and did not submit a memorandum of his defense.
The judgment shall be served to the convicted person in person, or by e-mail, or by any modern means of communication that can be saved and retrieved, in accordance with the conditions and regulations stipulated in the aforementioned Code of Civil and Commercial Procedure.
If service is not possible, it may be delivered at his place of residence to any of his relatives or in-laws living with him, or to his dependents. If none of them are found, or if the person found refuses to receive it, the notice shall be published in the Official Gazette, and posted in a prominent place at his residence or workplace, or in any other place deemed appropriate by the competent authority.

## Article (14)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall carry out the extradition procedures in coordination with the competent authorities.
The requesting state must take custody of the person sought for extradition within (30) days from the date of being notified of the extradition. If this period is exceeded, the extradition request shall be dropped, all its consequent effects shall cease, and the person sought for extradition shall be released.
The requesting state may request an extension of the extradition period for a similar period one time, provided that the extension request is submitted within the period stipulated in the preceding paragraph.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may order the detention of the person sought for extradition pending extradition upon approval of the request, in accordance with the periods mentioned in this Article.

## Article (15)
The rejection of an extradition request does not prevent reconsideration or the initiation of a new extradition case based on a subsequent request from the requesting state for the same crimes, in the event that new grounds emerge that have not been previously presented to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>.

## Article (16)
If the person sought for extradition is detained based on the extradition request submitted by the requesting state, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> must, upon rejecting this request, issue an order for his release.

## Article (17)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, the State shall bear the expenses of any procedures arising from the execution of the extradition request within its jurisdiction, and the requesting state shall bear the expenses of transporting the person sought for extradition, and any other expenses that arise during the extradition process.

## Article (18)
The Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig> or his representative may approve the transit of a person sought for extradition through the territory of the State from a state that has authorized the extradition to another state, based on a request from the latter state, provided that such transit does not harm the sovereignty, security, or public interests of the State.

# Chapter Two: Recovery of Persons from a Foreign State

## Article (19)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may request the recovery of persons sought for recovery from a foreign state, in accordance with the provisions of relevant international agreements or the principle of reciprocity, and in observance of the laws of that state.
The request shall be drawn up, accompanied by the data and documents stipulated in Article (6) of this Decree-Law, and the request shall be sent by the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> to the requested state through diplomatic channels.

## Article (20)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may, in cases that so require, request the competent authority in the requested state to arrest the person sought for recovery, or

## Article (21)
If the person whose extradition is sought has been detained for a period in the requested State in execution of the request referred to in the preceding Article, that period shall be deducted from the period of pre-trial detention or the period of imprisonment to which they were sentenced when it is executed in the State.

### Chapter Three: Handover and Recovery of Objects and Property and Controlled Delivery

## Article (22)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, the provisions of the laws in force in the State, and the rights of bona fide third parties, the Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig>, or their deputy, or any member of the Public Prosecution delegated by them, shall issue orders to seize objects used in the commission of the crime that were in the possession of the person whose surrender is sought, as well as proceeds of the crime seized with them, or at any subsequent stage after the commission of the crime, provided that these objects are related to the crime for which surrender is sought.
The Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig>, or their deputy, or any member of the Public Prosecution delegated by them, shall hand over the objects referred to in the preceding paragraph to the requesting State, even if the person sought is not surrendered for any reason, provided that the possession of the objects to be handed over does not constitute a crime in the State.
The Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig>, or their deputy, or any member of the Public Prosecution delegated by them, may temporarily hand over the aforementioned objects to the requesting State on the condition that they are returned immediately upon the conclusion of the procedures for which the surrender is sought, in the event that these objects or proceeds are the subject of other investigations in the State.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may temporarily retain these objects if they are needed for other criminal proceedings in the State.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> must recover the objects referred to in this Article to deliver them to their rightful owners, provided that their possession does not constitute a crime. If the rightful owners of these objects reside in the territory of the requesting State, that State may undertake to deliver them directly to them after the approval of the Public Prosecution.

## Article (23)
The Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig> or their deputy may authorize the transit of objects whose possession constitutes a crime, or which are proceeds of a crime, or were an instrument in the commission of a crime according to the provisions of the law, into or out of the State without seizure, or their complete or partial replacement under the supervision of the competent authorities. This shall be upon the request of a foreign judicial authority in accordance with the agreed-upon conditions, provided that such action would lead to identifying their destination or apprehending the perpetrators.
In all cases, the authorization referred to in the preceding paragraph may not be issued if it would harm the sovereignty of the State, its security, public order, public morals, or its environment.

### Part Three: Transfer of Sentenced Persons

## Article (24)
A request for the transfer of a sentenced person shall be submitted by the State, the State of enforcement, the sentenced person, or their legal representative, for the execution of final criminal judgments issued by the courts of the State against a citizen of a foreign country.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may approve the transfer of a person sentenced by a final judgment in the State to a custodial sentence, to a foreign country to which they belong by nationality, for the purpose of executing or completing the execution of their sentence therein, subject to the following conditions:
1- The crime for which the judgment was issued must be punishable under the laws of the State of enforcement by a custodial sentence of no less than six months.
2- The sentence imposed on the sentenced person must be a custodial sentence, and its duration, or the remaining period thereof, or the period eligible for execution, must not be less than six months.
As an exception, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may, according to its discretion and after coordination with the State of enforcement, approve the execution of a request to transfer the sentenced person if the period is less than six months.
3- The conviction judgment must be final.
4- The sentenced person must hold the nationality of the State of enforcement at the time the request is submitted.
5- The sentenced person must consent to the execution of their transfer request.
6- The conviction judgment must not have been issued for a crime involving public funds, a breach of military duties, or other crimes that would prejudice the sovereignty and security of the State or its public order. However, as an exception, the sentenced person may be transferred in cases of crimes involving public funds if they have paid the amounts of restitution and the fine imposed.
7- The sentence imposed on the sentenced person must not be the death penalty.

## Article (25)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may refuse to execute a request for the transfer of a sentenced person in the following cases:
1- If the acts for which the conviction judgment was issued are the subject of criminal proceedings being conducted by the judicial authority or competent bodies in the State.
2- If the execution of the request to transfer the sentenced person would prejudice the sovereignty of the State, its national security, or its public order.
3- If the sentenced person has not paid the fines and compensation awarded against them, and any other financial obligations that are due.
4- If the sentenced person is accused in other cases that have not been finally adjudicated, or has been sentenced to imprisonment in cases other than the one subject to the transfer request, and the sentence has not been executed.
5- If the sentenced person held the nationality of the State at the time of the commission of the crime for which the conviction judgment was issued.

## Article (26)
Without prejudice to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may request the transfer of sentenced citizens who are serving prison sentences abroad for their execution within the State.

### Part Four: Judicial Assistance in Criminal Matters
### Chapter One: Requests for Judicial Assistance Received by the State

Requests for judicial assistance shall be submitted in writing in the Arabic language by the competent authority in the requesting State through diplomatic channels, accompanied by all supporting documents, which must be dated, approved, and certified by that authority, unless an agreement to which the State is a party provides otherwise.
The request for judicial assistance must include the following data and information:
1- A statement of the requesting authority, the authority competent to investigate, their contact details, the legal proceedings subject of the request, the case number of the request, and the charge.
2- The facts under investigation or proceedings, specifying the place and date of their occurrence, a statement of the persons relevant to the substance of the request and their roles, the applicable legal provisions, and the provisions on the statute of limitations for the criminal case and the lapse of its penalty.
3- The purpose of submitting the request, the nature of the assistance required, the specified time for its execution, and any information related to specific procedures that the requesting State requests to be followed.
4- The identity, nationality, and location of the person or persons subject to the investigation or legal proceedings, with the identity document attached.
5- The reasons for believing that the evidence, items, or funds sought to be obtained, seized, or frozen are located in the requested State, supported by a judicial order issued by a competent judicial authority.
6- A detailed statement of the instrumentalities, properties, assets, or funds derived from the crime, including their location, and a statement of the reasons for believing that such instrumentalities, properties, assets, or funds are connected to a crime or were used in it.
7- A statement of the need, if any, to maintain the confidentiality of the information and data, and the reasons therefor.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may request additional information if it finds that the information contained in the request is insufficient for its proper execution.

## Article (28)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may execute judicial assistance in accordance with the provisions of this Decree-Law, and in accordance with the procedures in force in the relevant national legislation, the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, or the principle of reciprocity, within the scope of any of the following areas of cooperation:
1- Identifying persons or their whereabouts.
2- Taking evidence, hearing statements, obtaining affidavits, and interrogating the accused.
3- Presenting detained persons – other than citizens of the State – to give testimony or assist in investigations conducted by foreign judicial authorities.
4- Serving judicial documents, papers, and decisions.
5- Conducting joint investigations.
6- Requesting inquiries from the competent authorities.
7- Transfer of criminal proceedings.
8- Conducting controlled delivery.
9- Seizing items, searching persons and places, examining items, and inspecting sites.
10- Seizing, recovering, and tracing property, assets, and proceeds resulting from the commission of crimes.
11- Providing information, materials, data, and evidence.
12- Providing original documents and records or certified copies thereof.
13- Any other type of judicial assistance that does not conflict with the provisions of this Decree-Law, other applicable national legislation, the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party, or the principle of reciprocity.
A request for judicial assistance based on the principle of reciprocity must include an official, certified undertaking from the competent authority in the requesting State to the competent judicial authority in the State, containing a commitment to provide judicial assistance in similar cases and comparable situations in the future.

## Article (29)
The subject of the request for judicial assistance must fall within the jurisdiction of the competent foreign authority in accordance with the jurisdictional limits in the requesting State.

## Article (30)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may, upon a written request from a competent foreign authority and before the conditions set out in Article (27) of this Decree-Law are met, take precautionary measures necessitated by the need to protect threatened legal interests, or to preserve evidence or documents that are at risk of being lost or tampered with.
In all cases, these precautionary measures shall be suspended if the competent foreign authority fails to fulfill the conditions referred to in the preceding paragraph within a maximum period of (30) days from the date these precautionary measures were taken.

## Article (31)
The information contained in a request for judicial assistance may not be used for purposes other than its execution, when the request so specifies.
If a request for judicial assistance reveals a crime committed wholly or partly within the State, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall initiate investigation, disposition, and prosecution of this crime after obtaining the necessary authorization from the requesting State.

## Article (32)
Requests for judicial assistance shall be executed in accordance with the procedures stipulated in this Decree-Law and in a manner that does not conflict with the national legislation applicable in the State.
<page_end>10</page_end>

In cases where the competent foreign authority requests that a specific form of procedure be followed for the execution of the request, it must clearly specify this in the request, providing a full description of the required procedures and the reasons therefor, to determine whether or not the request can be executed in this manner.

## Article (33)

A request for judicial assistance related to hearing statements and obtaining testimonies from persons whose statements or testimonies are sought must include a full identification of the capacity and relationship of the person whose statement is to be taken to the facts of the case, and a statement as to whether they are a witness, an accused person, or an expert. It must also state the provisions applicable to each of them according to the laws of the requesting state, and a list of the questions to be asked or the information required from them.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall undertake the procedures for hearing statements and obtaining testimonies from the persons whose statements or testimonies are sought.
The competent foreign authority may request the presence of any of its competent representatives for the investigation procedures with the person whose statement is to be heard, whose deposition is to be taken, or whose testimony is to be obtained. The request must state the names and job titles of its representatives, specify a suitable date for their attendance, and state the reasons for the request. The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> has the discretion to assess the appropriateness and feasibility of fulfilling this request.
The attendance of any of these competent persons may be conducted through any means of communication.

## Article (34)

Subject to the provisions of Article (32) of this Decree-Law, if the subject of a foreign request for judicial assistance requires the transfer of a detained witness or expert to the requesting state, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may approve their transfer on the condition that they be returned within a period it specifies.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may refuse to transfer the witness or expert in the following cases:
1- If granting the request would prejudice the sovereignty or security of the state or conflict with its public order.
2- If the witness or expert does not consent to their transfer.
3- If the transfer of the witness or expert would endanger their life or the lives of their family members.
4- If the presence of the witness or expert is necessary for their appearance in a pending criminal case within the state.
5- If the transfer of the detained witness or expert would lead to an extension of their detention or if there are other reasons preventing their transfer to the requesting state.
In all cases, a detained witness or expert who is transferred to the requesting state shall remain in custody, unless the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> requests their release due to the expiration of the period or grounds for their detention. The requesting state shall bear the costs and expenses of the transfer of the detained witness or expert.

## Article (35)

If the request for judicial assistance includes a plea to obtain information or evidence, it must specify the type, content, and nature of this information or evidence, whether it relates to identifying persons and their data, or to funds, accounts, records, documents, objects, communications, or technical information of any kind. The type of procedures required to obtain them must also be specified.
The execution of the request may be refused if it is related to pending judicial proceedings in the state. It is also permissible to demand the return of any information or evidence after its delivery to the competent foreign authority, in accordance with the rules agreed upon with the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>.

## Article (36)

A request for judicial assistance involving the search of persons or places must include a full identification of the person or place to be searched, the items sought or expected to be found, and the evidence thereof, along with a statement of the connection of the person, or the place and its owner or possessor, to the facts of the case, with a statement of the reasons for such a search.

## Article (37)

If the request for judicial assistance pertains to the service of a judicial document within the state, the request must be accompanied by the original or an official copy of the document to be served, certified by the competent authority in the requesting state and translated into Arabic. The document must include a statement of its type, subject matter, reason, date, and the authority that issued and approved it.
The request must state the name and details of the person to be served with the document.

## Article (38)

The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may request the return of any property, documents, records, or instruments that have been delivered to a competent foreign authority in execution of a request for judicial assistance.

## Article (39)

Requests for judicial assistance related to the execution of foreign freezing and seizure orders must include a statement of the acts associated with the funds subject to the request, and these acts must be punishable under the laws of the state. The evidence must also be sufficient to show the connection of the funds requested to be seized and frozen to the facts and the accused persons.
The request must be accompanied by a certified official copy of the investigation records and the orders issued by the investigating authority or the competent court in the requesting state.

## Article (40)

Without prejudice to the rights of bona fide third parties, the Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig> or his representative may issue freezing and seizure orders, and the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> has the right to manage and dispose of the affairs of the funds as it deems appropriate.
Any interested party has the right to file a grievance before the Criminal Court <orig>محكمة الجنايات</orig>. The court must rule on the grievance expeditiously, either by rejecting it, revoking the order, or modifying it and establishing necessary guarantees if required. A grievance may not be filed again until three months have passed from the date of the ruling on the previous grievance.
The Public Prosecutor <orig>النائب العام</orig> or his representative may revoke or amend the order according to the considerations he deems appropriate.

# Article (41)

A request for judicial assistance for the recovery of the proceeds of a crime or their equivalent value must be accompanied by the confiscation judgment issued in the requesting State, and this judgment must be final and not subject to appeal.

The confiscation judgment may be non-conviction-based if the domestic laws of the requesting State so provide.

Requests for judicial assistance for the enforcement of foreign judicial confiscation orders or judgments are not directly enforceable, and the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> must conduct the necessary investigations to file a confiscation lawsuit before the Criminal Court <orig>محكمة الجنايات</orig>.

The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall initiate the confiscation lawsuit against the owner and possessor of the funds by means of a statement of claim filed with the court, which shall include the following information:

1- Information identifying the owner and possessor of the funds.
2- A statement of the funds for which confiscation is sought.
3- A description of the crime that is the subject of the lawsuit, with the applicable legal provisions.
4- The legal basis for the request for judicial assistance.
5- A statement of the evidence of the commission of the crime and its connection to the funds sought for confiscation.
6- A copy of the final, non-appealable confiscation judgment.

The lawsuit shall be filed in accordance with the procedures prescribed for filing a criminal case in felony matters as stipulated in the aforementioned Code of Criminal Procedure and Trials <orig>قانون الإجراءات والمحاكمات الجزائية</orig>, and the procedures, rules, and guarantees stipulated therein shall apply to all its stages, in a manner that does not conflict with the provisions of this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>, and the court shall decide the case expeditiously.

All of this is without prejudice to the right of the requesting State or third parties to pursue the direct recovery of funds, property, or assets by filing a civil lawsuit on their own behalf before the competent courts in the State.

In all cases, the aforementioned funds may not be confiscated if their owner or possessor proves good faith, and that they were obtained in exchange for providing services commensurate with their value or for other legitimate reasons, and that they were unaware of their source.

# Article (42)

The judgment issued in the confiscation lawsuit shall be served on the convicted party in accordance with the cases and procedures specified for the extradition lawsuit as stipulated in Article (13) of this Decree-Law <orig>مرسوم بقانون</orig>.

The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> or the convicted party may appeal this judgment before the Court of Appeal <orig>محكمة الاستئناف</orig> within (30) days, and this period shall commence in accordance with the rules and procedures stipulated in the aforementioned Article (13).

The judgment issued by the court shall be appealable before the Court of Cassation <orig>محكمة التمييز</orig> under the same rules and procedures prescribed for appealing criminal judgments.

In all cases, the judgment issued in this lawsuit may not be challenged by way of opposition <orig>المعارضة</orig>.

All judgments issued in confiscation lawsuits shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>.

# Article (43)

Any interested party, even if not a party to the confiscation lawsuit, may object to the judgment issued therein if their objection is based on their ownership of the funds prior to the confiscation, without knowledge of their illicit source.

The objection shall be filed with the court that issued the judgment within (30) days from the date of the judgment's publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>, by registering it with the clerk's office of that court <orig>إدارة كتاب هذه المحكمة</orig>. The objection must include a statement of the judgment being objected to and the grounds for the objection, otherwise it shall be void, and the court shall decide on it expeditiously.

The court hearing the objection may be composed of the same judges who issued the judgment.

The objection shall not suspend the execution of the judgment unless the court so orders. The acceptance of the objection shall result in a retrial of the case before the court that issued the judgment, limited to the part being objected to, without affecting the other convicted parties or the remaining confiscated funds.

The court may not annul or amend the judgment except to the extent required by the objection and the parts prejudicial to the objector, and only the person who filed the objection shall benefit from the judgment issued thereon.

As an exception to the preceding provisions, the objection shall be submitted to the court hearing the case if it has not yet been decided.

# Article (44)

The confiscation judgment may not be executed until it becomes final and (30) days have passed since its publication in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig>. The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall carry out the execution procedures in coordination with the competent authorities.

In the event of a judgment rejecting the confiscation, the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall issue an order to lift all precautionary measures <orig>الإجراءات التحفظية</orig> imposed on the funds subject to the confiscation lawsuit, unless the funds are under investigation in the State.

# Article (45)

The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may refuse a request for judicial assistance in the following cases:

1- If the execution of the request would prejudice the sovereignty of the State, harm its security, public order <orig>نظامها العام</orig>, or other essential public interests.
2- If the act on which the request is based does not constitute a crime within the State.
3- If the execution of the request conflicts with the laws of the State.
4- If the request relates to a crime for which the accused has been finally acquitted, has been granted a pardon, or for which the lawsuit is time-barred or the penalty has lapsed.
5- If there are substantial grounds to believe that the request for assistance was made for the purpose of prosecuting a person on account of their gender, religion, nationality, ethnic origin, or political opinions.

6- If the request relates to a crime under investigation or criminal prosecution in the State.
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may postpone the request if it conflicts with any judicial or legal proceedings within the State.
If the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> decides to refuse or postpone the execution of the request, it must inform the competent authority in the requesting State of the reasons for its decision.

## Chapter Two: Requests for Judicial Assistance Issued to Foreign States

### Article (46)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> shall be responsible for requesting judicial assistance from competent foreign authorities in accordance with the requirements of investigation and the execution of criminal judgments, pursuant to the provisions of international agreements to which the State is a party and the principle of reciprocity.

### Article (47)
Any measure taken or evidence obtained through judicial assistance from competent foreign authorities shall have the same legal or judicial effect as if it were taken by the investigation authority in the State.

### Article (48)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may establish channels of communication between itself and competent foreign authorities to secure and facilitate the exchange of relevant information in the field of judicial assistance, in accordance with the provisions of national legislation and international agreements.

## Chapter Three: Joint Investigations

### Article (49)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig>, in agreement with the competent foreign authority, may conduct a joint investigation or investigations concerning criminal matters related to ongoing investigations, prosecutions, or criminal judicial proceedings extending to one or more states, without prejudice to the sovereignty of the State on whose territory the joint investigation is conducted.

## Chapter Four: Service and Notification of Judicial Documents and Papers

### Article (50)
The Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> may send, through diplomatic channels or by any means it deems appropriate if necessary, requests for the service or notification of judicial documents and papers in criminal matters to any competent foreign authorities, for service within the jurisdiction of the requested State.
In all cases, the service or notification effected in the requested State shall be considered as if it were effected in the State.

## Part Five: Final Provisions

### Article (51)
In matters for which no provision is made in this Decree-Law, the provisions of the aforementioned Code of Criminal Procedure and Trials <orig>قانون الإجراءات والمحاكمات الجزائية</orig>, and any other relevant laws, shall apply to requests for international judicial cooperation.

### Article (52)
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdictions – shall implement the provisions of this Decree-Law. It shall be published in the Official Gazette <orig>الجريدة الرسمية</orig> and shall come into force from the date of its publication.

## Explanatory Memorandum for Decree-Law No. 79 of 2025 concerning International Judicial Cooperation in Criminal Matters

Whereas the effectiveness of cooperation and information exchange are crucial elements for success in confronting transnational crimes and in recovering funds and assets, as requests for international judicial cooperation in criminal matters are the cornerstone of international efforts to combat organized criminal behavior.
Mutual judicial assistance in the context of criminal matters is a procedural process by which states request and provide assistance with all evidentiary evidence for use in criminal cases. As for the extradition of criminals, it is the formal procedural process by which one state requests the enforced return of a person accused or convicted of a crime to be tried or to serve a sentence imposed upon them in the requesting state.

Whereas practical reality has revealed certain operational difficulties created by the absence of legislative texts regulating international judicial cooperation in criminal matters in all its forms, in addition to the State of Kuwait being party to a large and diverse set of international, regional, and bilateral agreements whose provisions relate to the scope of mutual legal assistance, extradition of criminals, and transfer of sentenced persons; and whereas the Amiri Order was issued on 10/5/2024, Article (4) of which stipulates that laws shall be issued by decrees-by-law, therefore, the present draft decree-by-law has been prepared with the aim of regulating international judicial cooperation in criminal matters.
The provisions of this draft are set out in (52) articles divided into five chapters. Chapter One, in Articles (1 and 2), addresses definitions and general provisions, assigning the jurisdiction to receive and execute requests for legal assistance and extradition exclusively to the Public Prosecution <orig>النيابة العامة</orig> in its capacity as the central authority for receiving such requests.
Chapter Two contains the provisions for the surrender of persons and objects in Articles (3 to 23), divided into three sections: the first titled (Surrender of Persons), the second titled (Extradition of Persons), and the third section dedicated to regulating cases of surrender and recovery of objects.
Chapter Three is titled Transfer of Sentenced Persons and includes Articles (24, 25, and 26), which stipulate the procedures for transferring sentenced persons to complete the execution of their sentences.
Chapter Four, in Articles (27 to 50), regulates the provisions related to various requests for legal assistance, their conditions, controls, and implementation mechanisms. This chapter is divided into four sections: the first is titled (Requests for Legal Assistance Received by the State) and includes Articles (27 to 45); the second is titled (Requests for Legal Assistance Issued to a Foreign State) and consists of three articles (46, 47, and 48); the third contains a single article, number (49), titled (Joint Investigations); and the fourth section, titled (Service and Notification of Judicial Documents and Papers in Other States), includes a single article, which is Article (50).
Finally, Chapter Five is titled Final Provisions and includes Article (51), and Article (52), which obliges the ministers, each within their respective jurisdictions, to implement the provisions of this decree-by-law, and specifies its effective date as the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

# Decree-by-Law No. 80 of 2025 Approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for the Avoidance of Double Taxation with respect to Taxes on Income and for the Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhu al-Qi'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And upon the proposal of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

We have issued the following Decree-by-Law:

## Article One
The Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for the Avoidance of Double Taxation with respect to Taxes on Income and for the Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance, signed in the city of Riyadh on 4 December 2024, the text of which is attached to this Decree-by-Law, is hereby approved.

## Article Two
The ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement the provisions of this Decree-by-Law, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

**Amir of Kuwait**

## for Decree-by-Law No. 80 of 2025
## Approving the Agreement between
## the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia
## for the Avoidance of Double Taxation with respect to Taxes on Income and the Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia have agreed to develop their economic relations and enhance cooperation between them in tax matters to avoid double taxation or tax evasion with respect to taxes on income (through arrangements to take advantage of tax agreements aimed at obtaining benefits provided by this agreement to achieve an indirect benefit for residents in third countries or jurisdictions).

This agreement was concluded between them in the city of Riyadh on December 4, 2024, and it includes thirty-one articles.

Article One came to specify the persons covered by this agreement and established a special provision for income derived by or through an entity or arrangement.

Article Two defined the taxes covered by this agreement, which are not limited to existing taxes but extend to include any tax imposed by the two states after the date of signing this agreement.

As for Article Three, it addressed the general definitions of the terms contained in this agreement.

Articles Four and Five were dedicated to defining 'resident' and 'permanent establishment'.

Articles (Six through Twenty) included special provisions regarding the taxation of income from immovable property, business profits, shipping, air and land transport, associated enterprises, dividends, income from debt-claims, royalties, income from technical services, capital gains, independent and dependent personal services, directors' fees, artistes' and sportspersons' fees, government pensions, and government services.

As for Articles Twenty-One and Twenty-Two, they specified the categories not subject to these taxes, namely teachers, researchers, students, and trainees.

Regarding government investments and other income, Articles Twenty-Three and Twenty-Four included their regulation.

Article Twenty-Five stipulated the methods for the elimination of double taxation, and Article Twenty-Six stipulated the Mutual Agreement Procedure <orig>إجراءات الاتفاق المتبادل</orig> for when a person considers that the taxation measures are not in accordance with the provisions of this agreement.

Finally, Articles Twenty-Seven through Thirty-One came to regulate the special provisions for the exchange of information, members of diplomatic missions and consular posts, entitlement to benefits, entry into force, and termination.

And whereas this agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait and does not conflict with its international obligations in the Arab and international spheres, and as the Ministry of Finance <orig>وزارة المالية</orig>, in its capacity as the competent authority, requested its signing, and as this agreement is considered one of the agreements stipulated in the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, as it relates to financial and tax matters, therefore, its approval must be by law in accordance with the provision of this paragraph, and whereas on 10/5/2024, the Amiri Order was issued, which stipulated in its Article (4) that laws shall be issued by decrees-by-law, accordingly, the present draft decree-by-law was prepared, and its first article provided for the approval of the accompanying agreement, and the second article obligated the ministers, each within their respective jurisdiction, to implement it, to be effective from the date of its publication.

</image># Agreement
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia for the Avoidance of Double Taxation with respect to Taxes on Income and for the Prevention of Tax Evasion and Avoidance

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, desiring to further develop their economic relations and enhance their cooperation in tax matters, and intending to conclude an Agreement for the avoidance of double taxation with respect to taxes on income without creating opportunities for non-taxation or reduced taxation (including through tax treaty-shopping arrangements aimed at obtaining reliefs provided in this Agreement for the indirect benefit of residents of third States or jurisdictions),
Have agreed as follows:

## Article One
### Persons Covered

1- This Agreement shall apply to persons who are residents of one or both of the Contracting States.
