## Article Four
## Resident

1- For the purposes of this Agreement, the term "resident of a Contracting State" means:

a) In the case of the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia:
- Any person who, under the laws of the Kingdom, is liable to tax therein by reason of his domicile, residence, place of incorporation, place of management, or any other criterion of a similar nature.

b) In the case of the State of Kuwait:
- An individual holding Kuwaiti nationality who has a permanent home in the State of Kuwait.
- A company or entity incorporated in the State of Kuwait.

However, this term does not include any person who is liable to tax in that State in respect only of income from sources in that State.

2- The term "resident of a Contracting State" also includes:

a) That State or any political or administrative subdivision, local authority, statutory body, agency, instrumentality, or public legal entity thereof.

b) Any entity directly or indirectly owned by the persons mentioned in paragraph (a) above, regardless of whether it is subject to tax or not.

c) Any institution established and operated exclusively for religious, charitable, scientific, cultural, or educational purposes.

3- Where by reason of the provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article, an individual is a resident of both Contracting States, then his status shall be determined as follows:

a) He shall be deemed to be a resident only of the Contracting State in which he has a permanent home available to him; if he has a permanent home available to him in both Contracting States, he shall be deemed to be a resident only of the Contracting State with which his personal and economic relations are closer (center of vital interests).

## Article Five
### Permanent Establishment <orig>المنشأة الدائمة</orig>

1. For the purposes of this Agreement, the term "permanent establishment" <orig>المنشأة الدائمة</orig> means a fixed place of business through which the business of an enterprise is wholly or partly carried on.

2. The term "permanent establishment" <orig>المنشأة الدائمة</orig> includes especially:
- a) a place of management.
- b) a branch.
- c) an office.
- d) a factory.
- e) a workshop.
- f) a mine, an oil or gas well, a quarry or any other place of extraction of natural resources.

e) The maintenance of a fixed place of business solely for the purpose of carrying on, for the enterprise, any other activity.
f) The maintenance of a fixed place of business solely for any combination of activities mentioned in sub-paragraphs (a) to (e).

    b) or the person does not habitually conclude contracts or play the principal role leading to their conclusion, but habitually maintains in that State a stock of goods or merchandise from which he regularly delivers on behalf of the enterprise.

The fact that a company which is a resident of a Contracting State controls or is controlled by a company which is a resident of the other Contracting State, or which carries on business in that other State (whether through a permanent establishment or otherwise), shall not of itself constitute either company a permanent establishment of the other.

For the purposes of this Article, a person or enterprise is closely related to an enterprise if, based on all the relevant facts and circumstances, one has control of the other or both are under the control of the same persons or enterprises. In any case, a person or enterprise shall be considered to be closely related to an enterprise if one possesses, directly or indirectly, more than fifty percent (50%) of the beneficial interest in the other (or, in the case of a company, more than fifty percent (50%) of the aggregate vote and value of the company’s shares or of the beneficial equity interest in the company) in the person and the enterprise or in the two enterprises.

## Article Six
### Income from Immovable Property

1. Income derived by a resident of a Contracting State from immovable property (including income from agriculture or forestry) situated in the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other Contracting State.

2. The term “immovable property” shall have the meaning which it has under the law of the Contracting State in which the property in question is situated. The term shall in any case include property accessory to immovable property, livestock and equipment used in agriculture and forestry, rights to which the provisions of general law respecting landed property apply, usufruct of immovable property and rights to payments for the working of, or the right to work, mineral deposits, and sources

3. The provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article shall also apply to income derived from the direct use, letting, or use in any other form of immovable property.

4. The provisions of paragraphs (1) and (3) of this Article shall also apply to income from immovable property of an enterprise and to income from immovable property used for the performance of independent personal services.

# Article Seven
## Business Profits

1. The profits of an enterprise of a Contracting State shall be taxable only in that State unless the enterprise carries on business in the other Contracting State through a permanent establishment situated therein. If the enterprise carries on business as aforesaid, the profits of the enterprise may be taxed in the other Contracting State but only so much of them as is attributable to that permanent establishment.

2. Subject to the provisions of paragraph (4) of this Article, where an enterprise of a Contracting State carries on business in the other Contracting State through a permanent establishment situated therein, there shall in each Contracting State be attributed to that permanent establishment the profits which it might be expected to make if it were a distinct and separate enterprise engaged in the same or similar activities under the same or similar conditions and dealing wholly independently with the enterprise of which it is a permanent establishment.

3. Where a Contracting State, in accordance with paragraph (2) of this Article, makes an adjustment to the profits that are attributable to a permanent establishment of an enterprise of one of the Contracting States and taxes accordingly profits of the enterprise which have been charged to tax in the other State, the other State shall, to the extent necessary to eliminate double taxation on these profits, make an appropriate adjustment to the amount of the tax charged on those profits. In determining such adjustment, the competent authorities of the Contracting States shall if necessary consult each other.

4. In determining the profits of a permanent establishment, there shall be allowed as a deduction expenses which are incurred for the purposes of the business of the permanent establishment, including executive and general administrative expenses, whether incurred in the State in which the permanent establishment is situated or elsewhere. However, no such deduction shall be allowed in respect of any amount, if any, relating to any nominal payment (other than for the reimbursement of actual expenses) made by the permanent establishment to the head office of the enterprise or any of its other offices in the form of nominal payments for the use of intellectual property, or by way of

Similarly, in determining the profits of a permanent establishment, there shall be no deduction for amounts (other than for the reimbursement of actual expenses) charged by that permanent establishment to the head office of the enterprise or any of its other offices, by way of royalties, fees, or other similar payments in return for the use of patents or other rights, or by way of commission for specific services performed or for management, or (except in the case of a banking enterprise) by way of income from debt-claims on the funds lent to the head office of the enterprise or any of its other offices.

h. Nothing in this Article shall prevent either of the Contracting States from imposing taxes on income or profits from any form of insurance or reinsurance activities in accordance with its regulations.

w. Where profits include items of income which are dealt with separately in other Articles of this Agreement, then the provisions of those Articles shall not be affected by the provisions of this Article.

z. If it is customary in a Contracting State to determine the profits to be attributed to a permanent establishment on the basis of an apportionment of the total profits of the enterprise to its various parts, nothing in paragraph (2) of this Article shall preclude that Contracting State from determining the profits to be taxed by such an apportionment as may be customary; the method of apportionment adopted shall, however, be such that the result shall be in accordance with the principles contained in this Article.

## Article Eight
### Maritime, Air, and Land Transport

1. Profits of an enterprise of a Contracting State from the operation of ships, aircraft, or road vehicles in international traffic shall be taxable only in that State.

2. For the purposes of this Article, profits from the international operation of ships, aircraft, or road vehicles shall include, but are not limited to, the following:
a) Profits from the full charter of ships, aircraft, or vehicles on a (time or voyage) basis that are operated in international traffic.

# Article Nine
## Associated Enterprises

1. Where:

a) an enterprise of a Contracting State participates directly or indirectly in the management, control or capital of an enterprise of the other Contracting State.

b) or the same persons participate directly or indirectly in the management, control or capital of an enterprise of a Contracting State and an enterprise of the other Contracting State.

And in either case, if conditions are made or imposed between the two enterprises in their commercial or financial relations which differ from those which would be made between independent enterprises, then any profits which would, but for those conditions, have accrued to one of the enterprises, but, by reason of those conditions, have not so accrued, may be included in the profits of that enterprise and taxed accordingly.

2. If a Contracting State includes in the profits of an enterprise of that State profits of an enterprise of the other Contracting State, and taxes them in that first Contracting State, and these included profits are profits that would have accrued to the enterprise of the first-mentioned State if the conditions between the two enterprises were the same as those that exist between independent enterprises, then the other State shall make an appropriate adjustment to the amount of tax imposed on those profits in that Contracting State. In determining such an adjustment, the other provisions of this Convention shall be taken into account, and the competent authorities of the two States shall consult

<header>

# Article Ten
## Dividends

1. Dividends paid by a company which is a resident of a Contracting State to a resident of the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other Contracting State.

2. However, such dividends paid by a company which is a resident of a Contracting State may also be taxed in that State and according to the laws of that State, but if the beneficial owner of the dividends is a resident of the other Contracting State, the tax so charged shall not exceed (5%) of the gross amount of the dividends. This paragraph shall not affect the taxation of the company in respect of the profits out of which the dividends are paid.

3. The term "dividends" as used in this Article means income from shares, mining shares, founders' shares, or other rights – not being debt-claims – participating in profits, as well as income from other corporate rights which is subjected to the same taxation treatment as income from shares by the laws of the State of which the company making the distribution is a resident.

4. The provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this Article shall not apply if the beneficial owner of the dividends, being a resident of a Contracting State, carries on business in the other Contracting State of which the company paying the dividends is a resident, through a permanent establishment situated therein, or performs in that other State independent personal services from a fixed base situated therein, and the holding in respect of which the dividends are paid is effectively connected with such permanent establishment or fixed base. In such case, the provisions of Article (Seven) or Article (Fifteen) of this Agreement, as the case may be, shall apply.

5. Where a company which is a resident of a Contracting State derives profits or income from the other Contracting State, that other State may not impose any tax on the dividends paid by the company, except insofar as such dividends are paid to a resident of that other State or insofar as the holding in respect of which the dividends are paid is effectively connected with a permanent establishment or a fixed base situated in that other State, nor subject the company's undistributed profits to a tax on the company's undistributed profits, even if the dividends paid or the undistributed profits consist wholly or partly of profits or income arising in such other State.

## Article Eleven
### Income from Debt-Claims

1. Income from debt-claims arising in a Contracting State, the beneficial owner of which is a resident of the other Contracting State, shall be taxable only in that other State.

2. The term "income from debt-claims" as used in this Article means income from debt-claims of every kind, whether or not secured by mortgage and whether or not carrying a right to participate in the debtor's profits, and in particular, income from government securities and bonds or debentures, including premiums and prizes attaching to such securities, bonds, or debentures. Penalty charges for late payment shall not be regarded as income from debt-claims for the purposes of this Article.

3. The provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article shall not apply if the beneficial owner of the income from debt-claims, being a resident of a Contracting State, carries on business in the other Contracting State in which the income from debt-claims arises, through a permanent establishment situated therein, or performs in that other State independent personal services from a fixed base situated therein, and the debt-claim in respect of which such income is paid is effectively connected with such permanent establishment or fixed base. In such case, the provisions of Article (Seven) or Article (Fifteen) of this Agreement shall apply, as the case may be.

4. Where, by reason of a special relationship between the payer and the beneficial owner or between both of them and some other person, the amount of the income from debt-claims, having regard to the debt-claim for which it is paid, exceeds the amount which would have been agreed upon by the payer and the beneficial owner in the absence of such relationship, the provisions of this Article shall apply only to the last-mentioned amount. In such case, the excess part of the payments shall remain taxable according to the laws of each Contracting State, due regard being had to the other provisions of this Agreement.

2- Nevertheless, royalties arising in a Contracting State may also be taxed in that State in accordance with the laws of that State, but if the beneficial owner of the royalties is a resident of the other Contracting State, the tax so charged shall not exceed (10%) of the gross amount of the royalties.

3- The term "royalties" as used in this Article means payments of any kind received as a consideration for the use of, or the right to use, any copyright of literary, artistic or scientific work, including cinematograph films, or films or tapes for radio or television broadcasting) or any patent, trade mark, design or model, plan, secret formula or process, or for the use of, or the right to use, industrial, commercial, or scientific equipment; or for information concerning industrial, commercial or scientific experience (know-how). The term "royalties" also includes payments received in respect of any profits derived from the alienation of any right or property described in this paragraph, to the extent that such profit is contingent on the profitability, productivity, use, or disposition of such property or rights.

4- The provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this Article shall not apply if the beneficial owner of the royalties, being a resident of a Contracting State, carries on business in the other Contracting State in which the royalties arise, through a permanent establishment situated therein, or performs in that other State independent personal services from a fixed base situated therein, and the right or property in respect of which the royalties are paid is effectively connected with such permanent establishment or fixed base. In such case, the provisions of Article (7) or (15) of this Agreement shall apply, as the case may be.

5- Royalties shall be deemed to arise in a Contracting State if the payer is a resident of that State. However, if the person paying the royalties, whether or not a resident of a Contracting State, has in a Contracting State a permanent establishment or a fixed base in connection with which the liability to pay the royalties was incurred, and these royalties are borne by that permanent establishment or fixed base, then such royalties shall be deemed to arise in the State in which the permanent establishment or fixed base is situated.

## Article Thirteen
### Income from Technical Services

1. Income from technical services arising in a Contracting State and paid to a resident of the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other State.

2. However, notwithstanding the provisions of Article (Fifteen) of this Agreement, income from technical services arising in that State may also be taxed in accordance with the laws of that State, but if the beneficial owner of such income is a resident of the other Contracting State, the tax so charged shall not exceed (10%) of the gross amount of the income from technical services.

3. The term "income from technical services" as used in this Article means any payment for any service of a managerial, technical, or consultancy nature, unless the payment is made:
  a) to an employee of the person making the payment.
  b) for teaching in an educational institution or for teaching by an educational institution.
  c) or by an individual for services for the personal use of the individual.

4. The provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this Article shall not apply if the beneficial owner of the income from technical services, being a resident of a Contracting State, carries on business in the other Contracting State in which the income from technical services arises, through a permanent establishment situated in that other State, or performs in that other Contracting State independent personal services from a fixed base situated in that other State, and the income from technical services is effectively connected with such permanent establishment or fixed base. In such case, the provisions of Article (Seven) or Article (Fifteen) of this Agreement, as the case may be, shall apply.

e. For the purposes of this Article, income from technical services shall not be considered to arise in a Contracting State if the payer is a resident of the other Contracting State through a permanent establishment situated in that other Contracting State and carries on business in that other Contracting State or performs independent personal services from a fixed base situated in that other Contracting State, and that permanent establishment or fixed base bears the liability associated with that income.

f. Where, by reason of a special relationship between the payer and the beneficial owner or between both of them and some other person, the amount for the technical services for which it is paid exceeds the amount which would have been agreed upon by the payer and the beneficial owner in the absence of such relationship, the provisions of this Article shall apply only to the last-mentioned amount. In such case, the excess part of the payments shall remain taxable according to the laws of each Contracting State, due regard being had to the other provisions of this Agreement.

## Article Fourteen
### Capital Gains

1. Gains derived by a resident of a Contracting State from the alienation of immovable property, referred to in Article (Six) of this Agreement, and situated in the other Contracting State may be taxed in that other State.

2. Gains from the alienation of movable property forming part of the business property of a permanent establishment which an enterprise of a Contracting State has in the other Contracting State, or of movable property pertaining to a fixed base available to a resident of a Contracting State in the other Contracting State for the purpose of performing independent personal services, including such gains from the alienation of such a permanent establishment (alone or with the whole enterprise) or of such a fixed base, may be taxed in that other State.

3. Gains derived by an enterprise of a Contracting State operating ships, aircraft, or vehicles in international traffic from the alienation of such ships, aircraft, or vehicles, or of movable property pertaining to the operation of such ships, aircraft, or vehicles, shall be taxable only in that State.

6. Gains from the alienation of any property other than that referred to in the preceding paragraphs of this Article shall be taxable only in the Contracting State of which the alienator is a resident.

# Article Fifteen
## Independent Personal Services

1. Income derived by an individual who is a resident of a Contracting State in respect of professional services or other activities of an independent character shall be taxable only in that State except in any of the following circumstances, where such income may also be taxed in the other Contracting State:

a) If he has a fixed base regularly available to him in the other Contracting State for the purpose of performing his activities; in that case, the income may be taxed in the other Contracting State, but only so much of it as is attributable to that fixed base.

b) If the person is present in the other Contracting State for a period or periods amounting to or exceeding in the aggregate (183) days in any twelve-month period commencing or ending in the fiscal year concerned; in that case, only the amount of income derived from his activities performed in that other State may be taxed in that other State.

## Article Sixteen
### Dependent Personal Services

1- Subject to the provisions of Articles (Seventeen), (Eighteen), (Nineteen), (Twenty), and (Twenty-One) of this Agreement, salaries, wages, and other similar remuneration derived by a resident of a Contracting State in respect of an employment shall be taxable only in that State, unless the employment is exercised in the other Contracting State. If the employment is so exercised, such remuneration as is derived therefrom may be taxed in that other Contracting State.

2- Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article, remuneration derived by a resident of a Contracting State in respect of an employment exercised in the other Contracting State shall be taxable only in the first-mentioned State if:
a) the recipient is present in the other State for a period or periods not exceeding in the aggregate (183) days in any twelve-month period commencing or ending in the fiscal year concerned.
b) the remuneration is paid by, or on behalf of, an employer who is not a resident of the other State.
c) the remuneration is not borne by a permanent establishment or a fixed base which the employer has in the other Contracting State.

3- Notwithstanding the preceding provisions of this Article, remuneration derived by a resident of a Contracting State in respect of an employment, as a regular member of the crew of a ship or aircraft operated in international traffic, other than aboard a ship or aircraft operated solely within the other Contracting State, shall be taxable only in the first-mentioned State.

## Article Eighteen
### Artistes and Sportspersons

1- Notwithstanding the provisions of Articles (Fifteen) and (Sixteen) of this Agreement, income derived by a resident of a Contracting State as an entertainer, such as a theatre, motion picture, radio or television artiste, or a musician, or as a sportsperson, from his personal activities as such exercised in the other Contracting State, may be taxed in that other Contracting State.
2- Where income in respect of personal activities exercised by an entertainer or a sportsperson in his capacity as such accrues not to the entertainer or sportsperson himself but to another person, that income may, notwithstanding the provisions of Articles (Seven), (Fifteen) and (Sixteen) of this Agreement, be taxed in the Contracting State in which the activities of the entertainer or sportsperson are exercised.
3- The provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this Article shall not apply to income derived from activities performed in a Contracting State by artistes or sportspersons if the visit to that State is wholly or mainly supported by public funds of one of the two Contracting States or its administrative or political subdivisions or local authorities. # Article Twenty
## Government Services

1- (a) Salaries, wages, and other similar remuneration shall be taxable only in the other Contracting State if the services are rendered in that other State and the individual is a resident of that State who:
  (1) is a national of that State.
  (2) or did not become a resident of that State solely for the purpose of rendering the services.

(b) Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (1) of this Article, pensions and other similar remuneration paid by, or out of funds created by, a Contracting State or a political subdivision or a local authority thereof to an individual in respect of services rendered to that State or subdivision or authority shall be taxable only in that State.

(c) However, such pensions and other similar remuneration shall be taxable only in the other Contracting State if the individual is a national of, and a resident of, that other State.

3- The provisions of Articles (Sixteen), (Eighteen), and (Nineteen) of this Agreement shall apply to salaries, wages, pensions, and other similar remuneration in respect of services rendered in connection with a business carried on by a Contracting State or a political subdivision or a local authority thereof.

## Article Twenty-Six
### Mutual Agreement Procedure <orig>إجراءات الاتفاق المتبادل</orig>

1- Where a person considers that the actions of one or both of the Contracting States result or will result for him in taxation not in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement, he may, irrespective of the remedies provided by the domestic law of those States, present his case to the competent authority of either Contracting State. The case must be presented within (three) years from the first notification of the action resulting in taxation not in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement.
2- The competent authority shall endeavor, if the objection appears to it to be justified and if it is not itself able to arrive at a satisfactory solution, to resolve the case by mutual agreement with the competent authority of the other Contracting State, with a view to the avoidance of taxation which is not in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement. Any agreement reached shall be implemented notwithstanding any time limits in the domestic law of the Contracting States.
3- The competent authorities of the Contracting States shall endeavor to resolve by mutual agreement any difficulties or doubts arising as to the interpretation or application of this Agreement. They may also consult together for the elimination of double taxation in cases not provided for in this Agreement.
4- The competent authorities of the Contracting States may communicate with each other directly, including through a joint commission consisting of themselves or their representatives, for the purpose of reaching an agreement in the sense of the preceding paragraphs. The competent authorities may, through consultations, develop appropriate bilateral procedures, conditions, methods, and techniques for the implementation of the mutual agreement procedure provided for in this Article.

## Article Twenty-Seven
### Exchange of Information

1. The competent authorities of the two Contracting States shall exchange such information as is foreseeably relevant for carrying out the provisions of this Agreement or to the administration or enforcement of the domestic laws concerning taxes of every kind and description imposed on behalf of the Contracting States, or of their administrative subdivisions or local authorities, insofar as the taxation thereunder is not contrary to this Agreement. The exchange of information is not restricted by Articles (First) and (Second) of this Agreement.

2. Any information received by a Contracting State under paragraph (1) of this Article shall be treated as secret in the same manner as information obtained under the domestic laws of that State and shall be disclosed only to persons or authorities (including courts and administrative bodies) concerned with the assessment or collection of, the enforcement or prosecution in respect of, or the determination of appeals in relation to the taxes referred to in paragraph (1) of this Article. Such persons or authorities shall use the information only for such purposes. They may disclose the information in public court proceedings or in judicial decisions. Notwithstanding the foregoing, information received by a Contracting State may be used for other purposes when the laws of both Contracting States permit its use for such purposes and the competent authority of the supplying State has authorized such use.

3. In no case shall the provisions of paragraphs (1) and (2) of this Article be construed so as to impose on a Contracting State the obligation:
a) to carry out administrative measures at variance with the laws and administrative practice of that or of the other Contracting State.
b) to supply information which is not obtainable under the laws or in the normal course of the administration of that or of the other Contracting State.

# Article Twenty-Eight
## Members of Diplomatic Missions and Consular Posts

Nothing in this Convention shall affect the fiscal privileges of members of diplomatic missions or consular posts or employees of international organizations under the general rules of international law or under the provisions of special agreements.

# Article Twenty-Nine
## Entitlement to Benefits

Notwithstanding the other provisions of this Convention, a benefit under this Convention shall not be granted in respect of an item of income if it is reasonable to conclude, having regard to all relevant facts and circumstances, that obtaining that benefit was one of the principal purposes of any arrangement or transaction that resulted directly or indirectly in that benefit, unless it is established that granting that benefit in these circumstances would be in accordance with the object and purpose of the relevant provisions of this Convention.

# Article Thirty-One
## Termination

1. This Agreement shall remain in force for an indefinite period, and either of the Contracting States may terminate it by giving written notice of termination—through diplomatic channels—to the other Contracting State no later than the 30th of June in any calendar year beginning after the expiration of a period of five (5) years from the year in which this Agreement became effective.

2. In such event, this Agreement shall cease to apply:
a) With respect to taxes withheld at source, on amounts paid after the end of the calendar year in which the notice of termination of this Agreement was given.
b) With respect to other taxes, for taxable years beginning after the end of the calendar year in which the notice of termination of this Agreement was given.

## Explanatory Memorandum
Of Decree-Law No. 81 of 2025
Approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development
Concerning the Establishment of a Headquarters for the Organization in the Arabian Peninsula Region

Stemming from the League of Arab States <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig> Resolution No. (2635), issued during the 53rd session of the League Council on 11/03/1970, which includes in its membership the Arab member states of the League of Arab States and is headquartered in Khartoum, and as this organization is concerned with issues of agricultural and fisheries development, food security, and combating poverty in Arab countries.

And whereas the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the Public Authority for Agriculture Affairs and Fish Resources <orig>الهيئة العامة لشؤون الزراعة والثروة السمكية</orig>, offered to host the headquarters of the Organization's regional office for the Arabian Peninsula region on 13/02/2012,

And whereas the Organization accepted this offer pursuant to the Organization's Assembly Resolution No. (20/32/J/A/2012), the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development <orig>المنظمة العربية للتنمية الزراعية</orig> have agreed upon an agreement comprising (10) articles as follows:

Articles (1, 2) stipulated the terminology and legal personality of the office, and Article (3) clarified the purpose of this Agreement, which is to define the tasks undertaken by the office through the privileges and immunities granted to it.

Article (4) stipulated the facilities provided by the State of Kuwait, Article (5) referred to the immunity of the office, Article (6) outlined communication facilities, Article (7) included the immunities and privileges of the office members, Articles (8, 9) referred to the application and interpretation of the Agreement and the settlement of disputes, and Article (10) stipulated the entry into force, amendment, and termination of the Agreement.

As this Agreement serves the interest of the State of Kuwait and does not conflict with its commitments in the Arab and international spheres.

And whereas it is considered one of the agreements whose ratification, according to its provisions, requires a law in accordance with the text of the second paragraph of Article (70) of the Constitution, and as the Amiri Order <orig>الأمر الأميري</orig> was issued on 10/05/2024, and Article (4) thereof stipulated that laws shall be issued by decrees, therefore, the accompanying draft Decree-Law has been prepared for its approval.

# Agreement
## Between
## The Government of the State of Kuwait
## And the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development
## Regarding
## The Establishment of a Headquarters for the Organization in the Arabian Peninsula Region

Pursuant to the League of Arab States <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig> Resolution No. (2635) issued during the 53rd session of the League Council on (11 / March / 1970), which includes in its membership the Arab member states of the League of Arab States <orig>جامعة الدول العربية</orig>, and is headquartered in Khartoum.

And whereas this Organization is concerned with issues of agricultural and fisheries development, food security, and combating poverty in Arab countries.

And whereas the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the "Public Authority for Agriculture and Fish Resources <orig>الهيئة العامة لشئون الزراعة والثروة السمكية</orig>", offered to host the headquarters of the Organization's regional office for the Arabian Peninsula region on (13 / 2 / 2012).

And whereas the Organization accepted this offer pursuant to the resolution of the Organization's General Assembly No. (20 / GA / 32 / 2012).

Therefore, the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig> and the Arab Organization for Agricultural Development <orig>المنظمة العربية للتنمية الزراعية</orig> have agreed as follows:

The Office shall enjoy the necessary legal personality, such as the capacity to contract, borrow, acquire movable and immovable property, and the capacity to litigate.

## Article 5
### Immunity of the Office

1- The premises of the Center's headquarters shall be inviolable, and no official or person exercising any public authority may enter it to perform any duty related to their function except with the express written permission of the President and under the conditions he agrees to. In case of necessity, there must be serious reasons for entering the Office.
2- The Government shall take all necessary measures to protect the premises and prevent any intrusion, material damage, breach of its security, or impairment of its dignity, provided that the Office premises are not used for purposes incompatible with its powers and objectives.
3- The archives and documents of the Center shall be generally inviolable.
4- The Office has the right to display its emblem in the designated place.
5- The funds of the Office and the means of transport and communication it uses shall not be subject to search, seizure, confiscation, or any similar coercive measures.

## Article 6
### Communication Facilities
The official correspondence and communications of the Office shall not be subject to censorship, and the Office shall have the right to use codes in its correspondence and communications. It shall also have the right to use all necessary means of communication, including diplomatic pouches. The Office has the right to install wired and wireless communication devices, subject to obtaining the necessary approvals for that. The Office shall also be exempt from all related fees and expenses.

## Article 8
### Application and Interpretation of the Agreement
Where no specific provision is made, the provisions of this Agreement shall be applied and interpreted in accordance with the relevant international conventions concerning the immunities and privileges granted to international organizations and their personnel in general.

## Article 9

## Explanatory Memorandum for Decree-Law No. 82 of 2025 Approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt in the Field of Military Cooperation

Affirming the support and backing of bilateral relations through military cooperation, based on mutual respect and taking into account the provisions of the United Nations Charter within a framework consistent with the national policies and legislations of both countries, an agreement was signed in the city of Cairo on 2/2/2025 between the Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>حكومة دولة الكويت</orig> and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt <orig>حكومة جمهورية مصر العربية</orig> in the field of military cooperation.
Article One stipulated the purpose of this agreement, which is to establish the pillars of relations that arise in the field of military cooperation and to define the foundations of cooperation between the two parties.
Article Two outlined the areas of military cooperation, including: military cooperation between the armed forces, military education and qualification, military training and exercises, logistics, supply, and catering, the exchange of experts, technicians, and professionals in various military, scientific, and technological fields, military intelligence, cybersecurity, military medicine and justice, armament and military industries, the exchange of activities in various sports, cultural, and social fields, and any other areas agreed upon by the two parties within the framework of implementing this agreement.
Article Three clarified the principles of implementation, whereby mutual benefit and the needs of both parties are taken into equal consideration when implementing this agreement. The two parties shall prepare annual plans for the implementation of joint activities through protocols and executive programs, and cooperation between the two parties shall be enhanced through the exchange of visits at all levels.
Article Four addressed the formation of a joint military committee between the two parties for the purpose of implementing and coordinating cooperation in all military fields by defining the primary areas of cooperation, exchanging information, presenting proposals, viewpoints, and recommendations to the competent authorities and periodically supervising them, providing opinions on the protocols emanating from this agreement, and convening emergency or additional meetings when necessary.
Article Five clarified the appropriate measures for the protection of confidential information and materials and the security of information obtained through tasks under the relevant security legislation. The two parties shall commit not to transfer documents, information, and materials to any third party except with prior written consent from the party from which the information originated. An equivalent classification of confidentiality shall be determined for the exchanged confidential information, documents, and materials, and their disclosure shall be prohibited even after the termination of this agreement.
Article Six stated that the provisions of this agreement do not prejudice the rights or obligations of either party arising from other international treaties and agreements.
Article Seven regulated financial matters on a case-by-case basis, whereby each party shall bear its own expenses. The receiving party shall bear the costs of accommodation, subsistence, and internal transportation for delegations until the agreed-upon activities are implemented, the treatment of emergency medical cases, and expenses related to various activities if stipulated in bilateral protocols between the two parties.
Article Eight stipulated judicial matters, whereby personnel of the sending party shall commit to respecting the laws, rules, and regulations in force in the territory of the receiving party during their presence on its land and shall not interfere in its internal affairs. In the event of a violation of the rules, the competent authorities of the sending party shall take appropriate action in accordance with their laws and military regulations.
Article Nine stated that any of the articles of this agreement may be amended upon a written request submitted by the party requesting the amendment to the other party.
Finally, Articles Ten and Eleven reviewed the final provisions regarding the entry into force of the agreement, its termination, its period of validity and renewal, and the method for settling disputes.
As this agreement serves the interests of both parties and does not conflict with the obligations of the State of Kuwait in the Arab and international spheres.
And whereas this agreement is considered one of the agreements mentioned in the second paragraph

## Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt in the Field of Military Cooperation

The Government of the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig>, represented by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>, and the Government of the Arab Republic of Egypt <orig>جمهورية مصر العربية</orig>, represented by the Ministry of Defense <orig>وزارة الدفاع</orig>, hereinafter referred to individually as (the Party) or collectively as (the Parties), based on the close fraternal ties between the two states and the friendly relations existing between them, affirming the support and strengthening of bilateral relations through military cooperation based on mutual respect, taking into consideration the provisions of the Charter of the United Nations, and within the framework that is consistent with the national policies and legislations of both states, have agreed as follows:

### Article One
**Objective**

This Agreement aims to establish the pillars of the relations that will be formed in the field of military cooperation and to define the foundations of cooperation between the two Parties.

### Article Two
**Cooperation in Military and Other Fields**

The two Parties shall achieve cooperation in the following fields:
1. Military cooperation between the armed forces.
2. Military education and qualification.
3. Military training and exercises.
4. Logistics, supply, and catering services.
5. Exchange of experts, technicians, and professionals in various military fields.
6. Scientific and technological fields.
7. Military intelligence and cybersecurity.
8. Electronic, information, and communication systems.
9. Military medicine.
10. Military justice.
11. Armament and military industries.
12. Moral guidance (military media).
13. Exchange of activities in various sports, cultural, and social fields.
14. Any other fields agreed upon by the two Parties within the framework of implementing this Agreement.

### Article Three
**Principles of Implementation**

1. The two Parties shall determine the details for the implementation of this Agreement through protocols and executive programs.
2. The two Parties shall prepare annual plans for the implementation of joint activities in accordance with this Agreement.
3. Mutual benefit and the needs of both Parties shall be taken into equal consideration when implementing this Agreement.
4. Cooperation between the two Parties shall be enhanced through mutual visits at all levels.

### Article Four
**The Joint Committee**

1. A joint committee shall be established, named the Kuwaiti/Egyptian Committee for Military Cooperation <orig>اللجنة الكويتية / المصرية للتعاون العسكري</orig>, (hereinafter referred to as the Committee), to implement the provisions of this Agreement and achieve its objectives.
2. The two Parties shall agree on designating the points of contact responsible for organizing and coordinating the Committee's activities.
3. The tasks of the Committee shall be defined as follows:
    a - Determining the primary areas of cooperation in accordance with Article (Two) of this Agreement.
    b - Identifying projects to be mutually agreed upon, defining appropriate forms of cooperation and their implementation methods.
    c - Exchanging information to achieve the proposed cooperation through the implementation of joint programs.
    d - Proposing suggestions, viewpoints, and recommendations and submitting them to the competent authorities.
    e - Ensuring the preparation of necessary documents for the implementation of approved projects and decisions.
    f - Periodically supervising the implementation of ratified projects and decisions.
    g - Evaluating the implementation of this Agreement and negotiating proposals for amendments to be made in accordance with this Agreement, at each meeting held between the two Parties.
    h - Providing opinions on the protocols arising from this Agreement.
4. The Committee shall convene by agreement of the two Parties, alternating between the State of Kuwait <orig>دولة الكويت</orig> and the Arab Republic of Egypt <orig>جمهورية مصر العربية</orig>. Additional or emergency meetings shall also be held when necessary.
5. The official invitation for activities shall be made by the head of the host Party at least two months before the proposed date of the Committee's meeting.
6. All topics on the Committee's agenda shall be prepared and coordinated at least (30 days) before the meeting.

### Article Five
**Protection of Confidential Information and Materials and Information Security**

1. The two Parties shall adhere to the confidentiality of information, documents, and classified materials obtained during their duties, respecting the relevant security legislation, regulations, procedures, and policies. Each Party shall protect the confidential information, documents, and materials that may be exchanged or provided by the other Party under this Agreement.
2. Information, documents, and materials shall not be transferred by any means to a third party, except after obtaining prior written consent from the originating Party.

3- The two Parties shall accord an equivalent degree of secrecy to the exchanged classified information, documents, and materials, provided that both Parties take the necessary security measures. The classified information, documents, and materials shall be used, transmitted, stored, and handled in accordance with the appropriate national security laws and arrangements within the scope of this Agreement.
4- Classified information, documents, and materials may only be transferred through governmental channels or channels agreed upon by the two Parties. The Party that prepared the classified information, documents, and materials shall determine their degree of secrecy.
5- Only persons authorized by the two Parties shall be permitted to access the classified information, documents, and materials, which shall be used for official purposes only. Such persons shall also have the appropriate official clearance.
6- The responsibility of the two Parties with respect to protecting and preventing the disclosure of the exchanged classified information, documents, and materials shall continue after the termination of this Agreement.
7- The two Parties shall respect patent rights and industrial and intellectual property rights related to the aspects of cooperation.

## Article Six
### Obligations of the Parties Arising from Other International Treaties
The provisions of this Agreement shall not prejudice the laws in force in either country, nor the rights or obligations of either Party arising from international treaties and agreements to which either of them is a party.

## Article Seven
### Financial Matters
1- Each Party shall bear its own expenses related to this Agreement, unless otherwise agreed upon by the two Parties on a case-by-case basis and in accordance with the regulations and limitations applicable to each Party.
2- In all cases, the Receiving Party shall bear the following:
a - Costs of accommodation, subsistence, and internal transportation for delegations from the point of arrival until the completion of the agreed-upon activities.
b - Treatment of emergency medical cases, including hospitalization in the Armed Forces Hospital or government hospitals.
c - Expenses related to various activities if stipulated in bilateral protocols between the two Parties.

## Article Eight
### Judicial Matters
1- The personnel of the Sending Party shall be obligated to respect the laws, rules, and regulations in force in the territory of the Receiving Party during their presence on its territory, in light of the principles of mutual respect and non-interference in internal affairs. The aforementioned personnel are prohibited from engaging in any activity that would affect the security and unity of the other Party.
2- The personnel of the Sending Party shall be subject to the criminal laws of the Receiving Party during their presence on its territory.
3- In the event that the personnel of the Sending Party violate military rules and discipline on the territory of the Receiving Party, the competent authorities of the Sending Party shall take appropriate action in accordance with their military laws and regulations.

## Article Nine
### Amendments
Either Party shall have the right to request an amendment to any of the articles of this Agreement. This shall be based on a written request submitted by the requesting Party to the other Party. Such amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in paragraph (1) of Article Ten.

## Article Ten
### Entry into Force Provisions
1- This Agreement shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels, in which the two Parties notify each other of the fulfillment of all internal national requirements necessary for its entry into force in accordance with their national legislation.
2- The provisions of this Agreement shall remain in effect for a period of three years, and shall be automatically renewed for similar periods, unless one Party notifies the other in writing of its desire to terminate this Agreement through diplomatic channels three months prior to its expiration date.
3- In the event of the termination of this Agreement, projects currently being implemented in accordance with this Agreement shall remain in effect until their completion, unless the two Parties agree otherwise.

## Article Eleven
### Settlement of Disputes
Any dispute that may arise concerning the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled through consultations and negotiations without recourse to a third party or local or international judicial authorities, through diplomatic channels between the two states.
This Agreement was signed in the city of Cairo on Sunday, 2/2/2025 AD, corresponding to 3 Sha'ban 1446 H, in two original copies in the Arabic language. A copy was delivered to the representative of each Party, and both have the same legal authority to be acted upon when necessary.
In witness whereof, the undersigned, being duly authorized by their respective governments, have signed this Agreement.

# Protocol on Media Cooperation and Exchange between the Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Ministry of Information," and the Government of the Republic of Turkey, represented by the "Turkish Radio and Television Corporation TRT"

The Government of the State of Kuwait, represented by the "Ministry of Information <orig>وزارة الإعلام</orig>," and the Government of the Republic of Turkey, represented by the "Turkish Radio and Television Corporation TRT <orig>مؤسسة الإذاعة والتلفزيون التركية TRT</orig>," hereinafter referred to as "the two Parties," in order to enhance cooperation between the two entities,
have agreed as follows:

### (Article 1)
This cooperation protocol aims to enhance and develop media cooperation and exchange between the two Parties and does not constitute an agreement under international law, nor does it create legal rights or obligations for the states of the two Parties.

### (Article 2)
Under this protocol, the two Parties shall obtain broadcasting rights for radio and television programs for the duration of the specified license period or through the free exchange of programs from a list of programs offered by the two Parties.

### (Article 3)
The two Parties shall send the programs requested from the offered list within two months from the date of the request. The text describing the provided program will be in Arabic/Turkish/English.

### (Article 4)
The requesting Party shall bear the costs of shipping and transporting the programs during the license period or free exchange.

### (Article 5)
The two Parties have the right to use the provided radio and television programs for the license or exchange period for their own programming only and do not have the right to transfer this right to third parties for broadcasting or any other purposes.

### (Article 6)
The two Parties are free to broadcast the radio and television programs partially or in full, without altering the content, or not to broadcast them at all.

### (Article 7)
In the event of any dispute regarding the interpretation or implementation of this protocol, it shall be resolved and settled amicably, provided that each Party abides by the provisions of the laws regulating intellectual property rights, copyright, and related rights in the other state.

### (Article 8)
The two Parties shall discuss their proposals for co-production separately by presenting topics, budgets, scripts, and technical and administrative contributions. The two Parties will also determine the production terms in a separate protocol for each production.

### (Article 9)
The two Parties shall, within the limits of their capabilities and capacities, work to participate in radio and television festivals, as well as in competition programs and cultural programs in both countries on a reciprocal basis.

### (Article 10)
The two Parties shall work to exchange information, expertise, and delegations from both countries on a reciprocal basis. The objective, duration, and conditions of this exchange will be determined separately.

### (Article 11)
The two Parties shall work to provide all technical facilities in the event of prior notification of the date of a visit by the other Party's media delegations for various reasons.

### (Article 12)
All costs related to filming by one Party in the state of the other Party shall be agreed upon separately, clarifying all conditions and methods of financial payment.

### (Article 13)
The two Parties shall inform each other, in writing, of their various offers for cooperation in media fields.

## (Article 14)
The two parties shall meet, when necessary, in the country of one of them as they may agree, in order to activate cooperation.

## (Article 15)
This Protocol shall enter into force on the date of the last notification by which one party informs the other of its fulfillment of the constitutional requirements stipulated in its national law necessary for the entry into force of this Protocol.
This Protocol may be reviewed or amended with the consent of the two contracting parties, and the amendments shall enter into force in accordance with the procedures stipulated in the preceding paragraph.
This Protocol shall remain in effect for a period of one year from its entry into force and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one party notifies the other in writing of its desire to terminate the Protocol at least 30 days prior to the date of termination.
This Protocol was signed in the city of Ankara <orig>مدينة أنقرة</orig> on April 8, 2021, in the Arabic, Turkish, and English languages, in two original copies for each language, with all texts being equally authentic. In case of divergence in interpretation, the English text shall prevail.

# SECTION 1
This Cooperation Protocol is concluded with a view to enhancing and developing cooperation between the Participants and does not constitute an agreement under international law. No provision of this Protocol shall be interpreted and implemented as creating legal rights or commitments for the States of the Participants.

# SECTION 2
The Participants will acquire the broadcasting rights for radio and television programs for a certain license period or will exchange programs free of charge from the program list offered by each participant.

# SECTION 3
The Participants will send the requested programs from the offered list, within 2 (two) months as of the request date. The explanatory text material of the provided programs will be in Arabic/ Turkish /English language.

# SECTION 4
The transport and freight costs of the programs that are acquired for a license period and/or exchanged free of charge will be borne by the requesting Participant.

# SECTION 5
The Participants will use the radio and television programs that are provided for a license period only for their own broadcasts and cannot transfer rights to third parties for broadcasting or any other purpose.

# SECTION 6
The Participants are free to broadcast the radio and television programs partially or in full, without changing their structure; or not to broadcast them.

# SECTION 7
Any dispute arising from the interpretation or implementation of this protocol shall be solved and settled amicably provided that each participant complies with the laws regulating intellectual ownership rights, the author's rights and the relevant rights in the other country.

# SECTION 8
The Participants will separately discuss their offers of coproduction by stating the production topics, budgets, script, technical and administrative contributions and determine the production terms in a separate protocol for every and each production.

## SECTION 9

The Participants will participate, reciprocally and within their means and abilities, in radio and TV festivals, competitions and cultural shows in each other's countries.

## SECTION 10

The Participants may exchange personnel for exchange of information and experience, on a reciprocal basis. The aim, duration and terms of this exchange will be determined separately.

# Decree No. 114 of 2025
## Approving the Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the Field of Industrial Cooperation

- Having reviewed the Constitution,
- And the Amiri Order issued on 2 Dhul-Qa'dah 1445 H, corresponding to 10 May 2024 AD,
- And upon the submission of the Minister of Foreign Affairs,
- And with the approval of the Council of Ministers,

**We have decreed the following**

### Article One
The Agreement between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the Field of Industrial Cooperation, signed in Kuwait City on 17 February 2025, the text of which is attached to this Decree, is hereby approved.

### Article Two
The Ministers – each within their respective jurisdiction – shall implement this Decree, and it shall come into force from the date of its publication in the Official Gazette.

**Amir of Kuwait**
**Mishal Al-Ahmad Al-Jaber Al-Sabah <orig>مشعل الأحمد الجابر الصباح</orig>**

**Prime Minister**
**Ahmad Abdullah Al-Ahmad Al-Sabah <orig>أحمد عبد الله الأحمد الصباح</orig>**

**Minister of Foreign Affairs**
**Abdullah Ali Abdullah Al-Yahya <orig>عبد الله علي عبد الله اليحيا</orig>**

Issued at Seif Palace on: 27 Dhul-Hijjah 1446 H
Corresponding to: 23 June 2025 AD

# Agreement
## Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the Field of Industrial Cooperation

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan, hereinafter referred to as "the Parties," desiring to enhance mutual cooperation between the two Parties in the field of industrial development,
Have agreed as follows:

### Article 1
The two Parties agree to exert their utmost efforts to increase cooperation in the field of managing techniques, sciences, and technical and technological developments related to the industrial sector.

### Article 2
In order to achieve the objective specified in Article 1 of this Agreement, the two Parties agree to establish a platform to:
- Promote cooperation in the development and support of the industrial sector in both countries.
- Organize seminars, conferences, training programs, workshops, and exhibitions in areas of mutual interest.
- Exchange expertise and studies in the field of developing and supporting small and medium-sized enterprises and business incubators.
- Exchange information and studies related to anti-dumping, countervailing duties, and safeguard measure agreements.
- Exchange expertise in the field of providing support and protection programs for national industry.
- Any other relevant and beneficial topics for industrial development.

### Article 3
The two Parties shall encourage the exchange of delegation visits to benefit from the experiences and developments related to the industrial sector in both countries.

### Article 4
The party requesting the services shall bear any financial costs resulting from the support provided under this Agreement, unless otherwise agreed.

### Article 5
The two Parties are committed to implementing this Agreement in accordance with the laws and regulations in force in both countries.

### Article 6
Any dispute arising from the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled through diplomatic channels and through consultation and negotiation between the two Parties.

### Article 7
The provisions of this Agreement shall not affect the laws in force in either country, or the rights and obligations arising for either Party under international treaties and agreements concluded between them.

### Article 8
1. This Agreement shall enter into force from the date on which the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan receives written notification from the Government of the State of Kuwait, through diplomatic channels, stating that it has completed all necessary national procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Agreement may be amended with the consent of both Parties, and the amendment shall become effective in accordance with the procedures referred to in the preceding paragraph.
3. This Agreement shall remain in effect for a period of five years and shall be automatically renewed for a similar period or periods, unless one Party notifies the other in writing of its desire to terminate it six months before the end of the original period or any subsequent extension period.
4. The termination of this Agreement shall not affect the implementation of any existing agreements, programs, or activities under this Agreement until their completion or expiration.

Done in Kuwait City on 17 February 2025, in two original copies, in the Arabic, Uzbek, and English languages, all texts being equally authentic. In case of divergence in interpretation, the English text shall prevail.

**For**
**the Government of the State of Kuwait**

## Article 4
### Implementation
The implementation of this memorandum shall be executed by the parties under certain work programs that are approved and agreed between the parties.

## Article 5
### Coordination and Follow Up
-Meetings shall be held periodically between the two parties upon the request of one of the parties, for follow up and evaluation.

## Article 6
### Confidentiality
-Each party agrees to treat as confidential all documents that are stated as confidential by the other party, which may include information and data obtained in the course of execution of this MOU parties can be used freely only after receiving consent from the providing party.

## Article 7
### Settlement of Disputes
Any dispute that might arise from the application or interpretation of this MOU shall be settled amicably through diplomatic channels or by consultation and negotiations.

## Article 8
### General Provisions
The provisions of this memorandum shall not prejudice the laws in force in either of the contracted parties toward their rights or obligations arising from their international contracts or memorandums previously committed to any of the contracted parties

## Article 9
### Amendments of the Memorandum
-By mutual consent of the parties to this MOU may be amended and supplemented, which are made out by separate protocols.
The protocols are considered integrative part of this MOU and enters into force in accordance with the provisions of article 10 of this MOU.

## Article 10
### Validity and Entry into Force
This memorandum of understanding shall enter into force on the date of receipt of the last written notification through diplomatic channels by which the parties notify each other of the completion of their procedures required for its entry into force.
-This memorandum of understanding shall remain in effect for a period of 5 years from the date of entry into force, and shall be renewed for on or more similar periods, unless one of the contracted parties inform the other party in writing of their desire to terminate this MOU six months prior to the termination date of the MOU, through the diplomatic channels.
-Terminating the MOU will not affect the activities and projects signed based on this agreement.

# AGREEMENT
Between the Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan in the Field of Labor Exchange in the Private Sector

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan, hereinafter referred to as the “Parties”;
Affirming the existing friendly relations between the governments and peoples of the two countries;
And desiring to establish bilateral relations based on mutual interests and benefits to enhance cooperation and coordination in the field of labor exchange;
Have agreed as follows:

## Article (1)
This Agreement aims to strengthen the bonds of cooperation in the field of labor, employment, and workforce development, and to emphasize the importance of the protection granted to expatriate labor in the private sector in accordance with the laws and legislations in force in both countries.

## Article (2)
The accredited authorities of the Parties responsible for the implementation of this Agreement are:
a) For the Kuwaiti side: The Public Authority for Manpower <orig>الهيئة العامة للقوى العاملة</orig> in the State of Kuwait.
b) For the Uzbek side: The Agency for External Labor Migration under the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan.

## Article (3)
The Parties shall facilitate the provision of relevant services to adopt and develop this cooperation within the framework of the existing laws, rules, and regulations in the states of both Parties.

## Article (4)
The Parties shall facilitate the transfer and employment of the workforce between the two countries, within the framework of the laws, rules, and regulations in force in the states of both Parties.

## Article (5)
The Parties shall conduct consultations or mutual visits in order to exchange knowledge and experience in the field of development and job creation.

## Article (6)
The Parties shall determine and implement the basic conditions of employment and the labor rights and duties for both the employer and the worker in accordance with the laws and regulations of the host country.

## Article (7)
In the event of a dispute between the employer and the worker, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with the regulations and legislations in force in the host country for amicable settlement. If an amicable solution is not reached, the dispute shall be referred to the judicial authorities.

## Article (8)
Workers from both Parties shall be permitted to remit funds to their home country under the laws in force in both countries.

## Article (9)
1. A joint working group shall be formed to undertake the following tasks:
- Ensuring the implementation of the Agreement.
- Interpreting the provisions of the Agreement, proposing amendments thereto as necessary, and resolving problems or difficulties that hinder the implementation of this Agreement.
- Analyzing job opportunities and proposing measures for technical cooperation, skills development, and supplying all sectors with skilled technicians in a manner that achieves mutual benefits for both Parties.
2. The joint working group shall meet once every year, alternating between each country, and upon the request of either Party.

## Article (10)
Any disputes arising from the interpretation or implementation of this Agreement shall be settled amicably through consultations between the Parties via diplomatic channels.

## Article (11)
1. This Agreement shall enter into force from the date on which the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan receives written notification from the Government of the State of Kuwait, through diplomatic channels, stating that it has completed all necessary national procedures for its entry into force.
2. This Agreement may be amended with the consent of both Parties, and the amendment shall become effective in accordance with the procedures referred to in the preceding paragraph.
3. This Agreement shall remain in effect for a period of five years, and shall be renewed

# AGREEMENT BETWEEN THE GOVERNMENT OF THE STATE OF KUWAIT AND THE GOVERNMENT OF REPUBLIC OF UZBEKISTAN IN THE FIELD OF EXCHANGE OF LABOUR IN THE PRIVATE SECTOR

The Government of the State of Kuwait and the Government of the Republic of Uzbekistan, hereinafter referred to as the Parties,
In confirmation of the friendly relations existing between the Governments and peoples of the two countries,
And desiring to establish bilateral relations based on mutual interests and benefits to enhance cooperation and coordination in the field of labour exchange,
The two Parties have agreed on the following:

## Article 1
This Agreement aims to strengthen cooperation ties in the field of work, employment, and workforce development, and to emphasize the importance of protection granted to expatriate workers in accordance with the legislation in force in both countries.

## Article 2
Authorities accredited by both Parties and responsible for implementing the Agreement:
A. From the Kuwaiti side: Public Authority of Manpower in the State of Kuwait.
B. From the Uzbek side: Migration Agency under the Cabinet of Ministers of the Republic of Uzbekistan.

## Article 3
The Parties shall facilitate the provision of relevant services to adopt and develop this cooperation within the framework of the existing laws, rules and regulations in the states of the Parties.

## Article 4
The two Parties shall facilitate the transfer and employment of manpower between the two countries, within the framework of the laws, rules and regulations in force in the states of the Parties.

## Article 5
The Parties shall conduct consultations or mutual visits in order to exchange knowledge and experience in the field of development and creation of opportunities.

## Article 6
The Parties shall determine and implement the basic conditions of employment and the rights and duties of work for both the employer and the worker in accordance with the laws and regulations of the host country.

## Article 7
In the event of a dispute between the employer and the worker, the dispute shall be resolved in accordance with the regulations and legislation in force in the host country to settle the dispute amicably. If an amicable solution is not reached, the dispute shall be referred to the judicial authorities.

## Article 8
Workers of both Parties are allowed to send money to their country of origin in accordance with the laws in force in both countries.

- Ensuring the implementation of the Agreement
- Interpreting the provisions of this Agreement and proposing amendments thereto as necessary and resolving problems or difficulties that prevent the implementation of this Agreement
- Analyze job opportunities and propose technical cooperation procedures, develop skills and provide all sectors with skilled technicians to achieve mutual benefits for both Parties.

4. Responsible Official:
   - In the State of Kuwait: The Director of the Department of Maritime Transport <orig>مدير إدارة النقل البحري</orig>.
   - In the Sultanate of Oman: The Director General of the Directorate General of Maritime Affairs <orig>مدير عام المديرية العامة للشؤون البحرية</orig> or his representative.
5. Certificate Procedures: means the procedures followed for granting certificates by the Competent Authority or maritime education and training institutions, and the control and supervision procedures for implementing the requirements of the Convention in the training, assessment of competency, and issuance of certificates for seafarers (mariners) in accordance with the requirements of the Convention and its Code.
6. Endorsement of Certificate: means a document confirming the recognition of a certificate of competency issued by the Competent Authority – in accordance with the provisions of the Convention and its Code, and in accordance with the national legislation of the Party that issued it – which grants the holder the right to serve on a ship in accordance with the level of the certificate obtained.

## Article (2)
### Communications of the Parties
1. For the purposes of implementing this Memorandum, each Party shall provide the other Party with the relevant mailing addresses, contact numbers, and email addresses as follows:
   (a) For the State of Kuwait:
   Department of Maritime Transport <orig>إدارة النقل البحري</orig>
   General Directorate of Coast Guard <orig>الإدارة العامة لخفر السواحل</orig>
   Ministry of Interior <orig>وزارة الداخلية</orig>
   P.O. Box: 318 Safat, Postal Code: 11111 – Kuwait
   Telephone No.: +965 1888050 Ext: 6025
   Fax No.: +965 23906257
   Email: seafarers@moi.gov.kw
   (b) For the Sultanate of Oman:
   Directorate General of Maritime Affairs <orig>المديرية العامة للشؤون البحرية</orig>
   Ministry of Transport, Communications and Information Technology <orig>وزارة النقل والاتصالات وتقنية المعلومات</orig>
   P.O. Box: 684 Muscat, Postal Code: 100
   Telephone No.: +968 24685971
   Email: seafarers@omcit.gov.om
2. In the event that either Party modifies the mailing addresses, contact numbers, or email addresses referred to in paragraph (1) of this Article, it shall immediately notify the other Party in writing of these modifications.

## Article (3)
### Recognition of Certificate
1. In implementation of the provisions of Regulation (I/10) of the Convention and its Code, the Competent Authority shall undertake to recognize and endorse the certificates issued by the Certificate Issuing Authority of the other Party, after that Party commits to ensuring the following:
   (a) That seafarers are trained and assessed in accordance with the provisions of Section (A-I/6) of the Convention Code.
   (b) That those responsible for the training and assessment referred to in the preceding paragraph are appropriately qualified in accordance with the provisions of Section (A-I/6) of the Convention Code.
   (c) That certificates are registered in a special numbered register for those certificates.
2. The Competent Authority shall permit visits to its facilities by the other Party for the purpose of reviewing the procedures for issuing certificates, in accordance with the provisions of Regulation (I/10) of the Convention, to verify compliance with the requirements of the Convention in terms of the following:
   (a) Standards of competence.
   (b) Issuance, endorsement, revalidation, and cancellation of certificates.
   (c) Registration of certificates in a special register.
   (d) Standards of medical fitness.
   (e) Communication and the process of responding to verification requests.
3. The Certificate Issuing Authority in the country of one Party shall notify the Competent Authority of the other Party within sixty (60) days of any amendments to the training system and procedures for issuing certificates of competency, and of any amendments that could lead to a difference in the information sent to the Secretary-General of the Organization.
